Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Multiple sclerosis (MS) diagnosis relies on dissemination in space (DIS) and time (DIT) per the 2017 McDonald criteria.
• DIS: ≥1 T2 lesions in ≥2 of four typical CNS regions (periventricular, juxtacortical, infratentorial, spinal).
• DIT: Simultaneous presence of enhancing and non-enhancing lesions or new lesions on follow-up MRI.
Early initiation of disease-modifying therapy (DMT) after fulfilling diagnostic criteria reduces relapse rates and delays disability accumulation. Incontinence and leg weakness indicate a clinically isolated syndrome progressing to relapsing MS.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The patient has two periventricular T2 lesions plus multiple spinal lesions (DIS) and one enhancing plus at least one non-enhancing lesion (DIT). According to the 2017 McDonald criteria and supported by multiple randomized trials (e.g., CHAMPS, BENEFIT), initiation of a DMT—such as interferon-β, glatiramer acetate, or high-efficacy agents in high-risk patients—is indicated immediately upon diagnosis. The 2018 ECTRIMS/EAN guideline (level A) recommends early treatment to reduce relapse rate by ~30–50% and limit new MRI lesions. Delaying therapy risks accrual of irreversible axonal damage.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Repeat MRI in 6 months
• Why incorrect: DIT already established by simultaneous enhancing/non-enhancing lesions; no diagnostic uncertainty remains.
• Misconception: Belief that waiting confirms new lesions rather than using existing enhancement patterns.
C. Perform lumbar puncture for oligoclonal bands
• Why incorrect: OCBs support MS but are not required once McDonald criteria are met; adding LP would delay treatment.
• Misconception: Over-reliance on CSF when MRI criteria suffice.
D. Symptomatic management only
• Why incorrect: Passive approach ignores disease-modifying agents proven to slow disability; symptomatic care alone does not alter inflammatory activity.
• Misconception: Confusing acute relapse treatment with long-term disease control.

Clinical Pearls

• Enhancement patterns on baseline MRI can establish DIT without waiting for new lesions.
• Early DMT initiation reduces conversion from CIS to CDMS by ~45% over 3 years (CHAMPS trial).
• High-efficacy therapies (e.g., natalizumab, ocrelizumab) are preferred in patients with poor prognostic factors (e.g., early disability).

1. Assuming LP for OCBs is mandatory before treatment—MRI criteria now suffice per McDonald rules.
2. Waiting for new clinical relapses or new lesions on follow-up MRI delays neuroprotection and worsens outcomes.

• ECTRIMS/EAN Guideline 2018: “Initiate DMT at first diagnosis of relapsing MS once DIS and DIT criteria are met” (Level A evidence).
• CHAMPS Trial (McFarland et al., Lancet 2000): Early interferon-β-1a in CIS reduces conversion to clinically definite MS by 50% at 3 years (Level I evidence).

[Exam: Part I 2023] Demyelinating disorders of the central nervous system present with optic neuritis (ON) and myelitis. Key concepts:
• Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (LETM) spans ≥3 vertebral segments, characteristic of NMOSD and MOGAD, but rare in MS.
• Aquaporin‐4 (AQP4) antibodies define classic NMOSD; AQP4‐negative LETM suggests alternative seronegative variants, notably MOG antibody‐associated disease (MOGAD).

A. Relapsing remitting multiple sclerosis
• MS myelitis lesions are typically short (<2 vertebral segments) and peripheral.
• MRI in MS shows periventricular “Dawson’s fingers” and dissemination in space/time.

B. Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder
• Defined by AQP4‐IgG positivity in ~80% of cases; seronegative NMOSD requires strict criteria and MOG testing.
• AQP4‐negative LETM with MOG‐IgG positivity is reclassified as MOGAD, not classic NMOSD.

C. Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis
• Predominantly pediatric, monophasic with encephalopathy and multifocal brain lesions.
• Adults with relapsing ON and isolated LETM without encephalopathy argue against ADEM.

2. Assuming ADEM only occurs in children—adult ADEM is rare and usually monophasic with encephalopathy.

• 2015 International Panel for NMO Diagnosis (IPND): defined NMOSD criteria requiring AQP4‐IgG for seropositive cases (Level A evidence).
• 2022 EAN/ERN MOGAD Consensus Guideline: recommends MOG‐IgG cell‐based assay in AQP4‐negative LETM or ON (Level B evidence); advocates long‐term maintenance immunotherapy in relapsing MOGAD.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lesions in MOGAD preferentially affect central spinal grey matter due to high MOG expression on oligodendrocyte processes, causing symmetric T2 hyperintensity in axial images (“H‐sign”).

Anti‐MOG antibodies activate complement on the myelin sheath of oligodendrocytes, leading to demyelination, macrophage infiltration, and reversible conduction block—distinct from astrocytopathy in AQP4‐positive NMOSD.

1. Clinical presentation of ON ± LETM
2. MRI of brain and spine: identify LETM (≥3 segments)

• MOGAD LETM often extends into the conus and is centrally located;
• Absence of Dawson’s fingers or periventricular plaques helps exclude MS.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Acute: IV methylprednisolone 1 g/day ×5 days; consider plasma exchange for steroid‐refractory attacks.
Maintenance in relapsing MOGAD: slow oral steroid taper plus immunosuppressants (azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil); rituximab less effective than in NMOSD.

[Exam: Part II 2018] Optic neuritis is often the first clinically isolated syndrome (CIS) heralding multiple sclerosis (MS). Key concepts:
1. Demyelination of the optic nerve leads to visual loss and pain on eye movement.
2. Brain MRI lesions predict higher MS risk; a normal MRI at presentation confers a lower conversion rate.
3. CIS prognosis hinges on dissemination in space (DIS) and time (DIT) per McDonald criteria, with MRI serving as a surrogate marker.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Longitudinal data from the Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial (ONTT; Beck et al., Arch Ophthalmol 2003) demonstrate that among patients presenting with typical optic neuritis and a normal baseline brain MRI:
• 5-year cumulative risk of clinically definite MS was ~16–17%.
• 10-year risk rose to ~22%.
• 15-year risk reached ~25%.
Current consensus often cites the 15-year figure (~25%) when no lesions are seen initially. The 2017 McDonald criteria emphasize MRI lesion count for risk stratification but do not alter these long-term probabilities (Thompson et al., Lancet Neurol 2018).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. 16% risk of conversion to MS
• Reflects ~5-year conversion rate, not the standard long‐term (15-year) estimate. Boards typically reference the 15-year figure.
B. 25% risk of conversion to MS
• Correct: aligns with the 15-year cumulative risk in ONTT for normal MRI CIS.
C. 51% risk of conversion to MS
• Mirrors 10-year risk in patients *with* ≥1 brain lesion, not those with a normal scan. Conflates high-risk subgroup data.
D. 10% risk of conversion to MS
• Underestimates even the 1-year conversion (~8%), and is not used for longer‐term prognostication.

- A normal brain MRI in optic neuritis predicts a relatively low (~25% at 15 years) MS conversion rate; discuss this in counseling.
• Oligoclonal bands in CSF raise conversion risk independently of MRI findings—consider lumbar puncture if high clinical suspicion.
• Early high-efficacy disease-modifying therapy may be considered in high-risk CIS (e.g., Gd-enhancing lesions) to delay MS onset.

1. Equating the 5-year risk (16%) with the overall long-term risk used in boards (25%).
2. Applying the high-risk conversion rates from patients with baseline MRI lesions to those with normal scans.
3. Assuming a normal MRI excludes future MS development—low risk, not zero.

• Recommendation: In CIS with normal MRI, discuss watchful waiting vs. early DMT based on individual risk factors (oligoclonal bands, clinical severity) (Evidence level 2).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] Optic neuritis is an acute, immune-mediated demyelination of the optic nerve, classically presenting with unilateral vision loss, periocular pain, and a relative afferent pupillary defect. It is often the first clinical manifestation of multiple sclerosis (MS). Brain MRI showing white-matter lesions increases the 15-year risk of developing clinically definite MS to ~75%. Acute management aims to rapidly reduce inflammation and restore conduction, while disease-modifying therapies (DMTs) are considered subsequently to alter long-term conversion risk. Understanding the distinction between urgent immunosuppression (steroids) and longer-term immunomodulation (beta-interferon) is key.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial (ONTT, 1992) demonstrated that high-dose IV methylprednisolone (1 g/day for 3 days) followed by oral prednisone accelerates visual recovery (Level I evidence), though it does not change the ultimate visual outcome or long-term MS risk. The 2016 AAN Practice Parameter endorses corticosteroids as first-line acute therapy (Level B recommendation). Immediate steroid administration reduces optic nerve edema, restores saltatory conduction, and shortens the duration of symptoms. Beta-interferon DMTs are indicated after diagnosis of clinically isolated syndrome (CIS) with high MRI lesion burden to delay conversion to MS (CHAMPS, ETOMS trials), but are not appropriate as the initial acute intervention.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Start beta-interferon therapy
• Incorrect: DMTs reduce future MS risk but do not address acute inflammation or speed visual recovery.
• Misconception: Confusing chronic CIS management with urgent treatment.
• Differentiator: Onset of action for interferons is weeks to months, not hours to days.

C. Schedule for follow-up MRI
• Incorrect: Defers necessary treatment; acute steroids should not await further imaging.
• Misconception: Overreliance on serial imaging rather than clinical urgency.
• Differentiator: Imaging follows treatment, not precedes initial management when presentation is classic.

D. Refer to a neurologist
• Incorrect: Referral delays definitive therapy; ophthalmology/neurology consult is often simultaneous with steroid initiation.
• Misconception: Thinking that optic neuritis must always be managed by a specialist before treatment.
• Differentiator: Steroids can and should be started immediately once diagnosis is made.

- High-dose IV methylprednisolone should be followed by an oral prednisone taper; avoid oral prednisone alone (0.5 mg/kg) due to increased relapse rate.
• Pain with extraocular movements and a relative afferent pupillary defect are ≥95% sensitive for optic neuritis in MS.
• Even with normal MRI, a first episode of optic neuritis warrants steroids to hasten recovery, though DMT decisions depend on lesion load.

- Equating acute immunosuppression with long-term disease modification (steroids vs interferon).
• Waiting for repeat imaging before initiating treatment in a classic presentation.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Miller Fisher syndrome (MFS) is an acute, immune-mediated neuropathy and a recognized variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome.
• It is characterized by the triad of ophthalmoplegia (III, IV, VI cranial nerves), gait ataxia (proprioceptive sensory fiber involvement), and areflexia.
• Pathophysiology hinges on anti-GQ1b IgG antibodies that bind to ganglioside GQ1b, abundant on oculomotor nerves, activating complement and causing demyelination at peripheral nerve nodes of Ranvier.
• Clinically, MFS often follows a viral illness by 1–2 weeks and demonstrates albuminocytologic dissociation on CSF analysis. Early immunotherapy alters the course and speeds recovery.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) is the first-line therapy for MFS because it neutralizes pathogenic antibodies, blocks Fc receptors, and attenuates complement activation. In a landmark randomized trial of Guillain-Barré variants (French Cooperative Group, NEJM 1997), IVIG (0.4 g/kg/day × 5 days) was as effective as plasmapheresis in accelerating recovery but had a superior safety profile in cranial-nerve-predominant syndromes. The Joint EFNS/PNS guideline (2010) assigns Level A evidence to both IVIG and plasmapheresis in GBS/MFS, but clinical consensus favors IVIG for ease of administration and fewer adverse events in MFS. Corticosteroids have been shown in multiple RCTs (Hughes et al., Brain 2001) to be ineffective or harmful. Supportive care alone leads to protracted recovery and higher morbidity.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Plasmapheresis (Plex)
• Though plasmapheresis removes circulating anti-GQ1b antibodies, it carries increased risks (central venous access, hypotension) and is less practical for isolated cranial neuropathies.
• Misconception: All GBS variants respond equally to plasmapheresis; in MFS, IVIG’s convenience and lower complication rate make it preferable.

C. Corticosteroids
• High-dose steroids do not alter disease course in immune-mediated demyelination of GBS/MFS; some trials suggest delayed nerve conduction recovery.
• Misconception: “Autoimmune” implies steroid responsiveness; however, humoral processes in GBS/MFS do not improve with steroids.

D. Supportive care only
• Without immunotherapy, antibody-mediated complement activation continues, leading to slower resolution and potential respiratory compromise.
• Misconception: MFS is always benign and self-resolving; immunotherapy significantly reduces time to functional recovery.

Clinical Pearls

- Anti-GQ1b IgG is positive in >90% of MFS patients and correlates with ophthalmoplegia severity.
• IVIG dosing for MFS mirrors GBS: 2 g/kg divided over 5 days; infuse slowly to mitigate headache and thrombotic risk.
• Monitor forced vital capacity even if limb strength is preserved—respiratory involvement can be insidious.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming corticosteroids improve recovery in all autoimmune neuropathies—GBS/MFS pathogenesis is complement-mediated, not T-cell-driven.
2. Believing that MFS does not require immunotherapy because it "resolves spontaneously"—untreated cases take 6–8 weeks versus 2–4 weeks with IVIG.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Joint Task Force of EFNS/PNS Guideline on GBS Management, 2010
• Recommendation: IVIG (0.4 g/kg/day for 5 days) or plasmapheresis (4–6 exchanges) as first-line therapy.
• Level of Evidence: A (multiple RCTs/meta-analyses).

2. National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Guideline NG146, 2020
• Recommendation: Offer IVIG over plasmapheresis in variants with predominant cranial nerve involvement due to safety and ease.
• Level of Evidence: 1++ (high-quality systematic reviews of RCTs).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Oculomotor (III), trochlear (IV), and abducens (VI) nerves express high densities of GQ1b ganglioside at the paranodal regions, explaining selective ophthalmoplegia.
• Large-diameter proprioceptive fibers in dorsal roots contribute to gait ataxia when demyelinated.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

1. Antecedent infection triggers cross-reactive anti-ganglioside (GQ1b) IgG production.
2. IgG binds to gangliosides on cranial and peripheral nerves, fixing complement.
3. Membrane attack complexes form at the nodes of Ranvier, causing demyelination and conduction block.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical triad: ophthalmoplegia + ataxia + areflexia
2. CSF: albuminocytologic dissociation (elevated protein, normal cell count)
3. Nerve conduction studies: reduced sensory and motor nerve conduction velocities
4. Serology: anti-GQ1b IgG
5. Initiate IVIG promptly once MFS is diagnosed.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Brain MRI is typically normal; contrast may show mild cranial nerve root enhancement in a minority of cases.
• Imaging is mainly used to exclude alternative causes of ophthalmoplegia (e.g., cavernous sinus thrombosis).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- IVIG 2 g/kg total dose over 2–5 days: monitor renal function, hydration, and infusion rate to reduce headache and thrombosis risk.
• Plasmapheresis protocol: 4–6 exchanges over 8–10 days; requires central venous access and hemodynamic monitoring.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam. Miller Fisher syndrome treatment questions frequently test the distinction between IVIG, plasmapheresis, and steroids. Variants of Guillain-Barré syndrome, especially MFS, are commonly assessed in both U.S. and regional board exams as single-best-answer vignettes focusing on immunotherapy choice and antibody correlations.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] - In AIDP (the most common form of Guillain-Barré syndrome), immune-mediated demyelination of peripheral nerve roots disrupts the blood-nerve barrier, allowing albumin to leak into CSF without recruiting leukocytes.
• “Albuminocytologic dissociation” is defined as CSF protein >45 mg/dL (0.45 g/L) with a normal cell count (<10 cells/µL).
• This pattern helps distinguish AIDP from infectious or central inflammatory processes (e.g., Lyme radiculitis, MS), which show pleocytosis or oligoclonal bands.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The hallmark CSF finding in AIDP is albuminocytologic dissociation (Option A). The 2010 American Academy of Neurology (AAN) practice parameter for GBS diagnosis cites CSF protein >0.55 g/L with <10 cells/mm³ as supportive (Level B). EFNS/PNS guidelines (2010; updated 2021) note that >50% of patients after 1 week of symptom onset demonstrate this pattern, peaking at 4 weeks. Pathophysiologically, segmental demyelination and complement-mediated injury at the nerve roots increase vascular permeability to proteins but not leukocytes. By contrast, infectious polyradiculitis yields CSF pleocytosis (>10–50 cells/µL) and MS shows oligoclonal IgG synthesis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

Option B: “Elevated white blood cell count with lymphocytic predominance.”
• Inappropriate for GBS; pleocytosis (>10 cells/µL) suggests infection (e.g., Lyme, HIV).
• Misconception: equating any neuropathy with central inflammatory CSF changes.

Option C: “Normal protein and elevated cell count.”
• Fails to recognize that protein leak is central to albuminocytologic dissociation.
• Suggests purely infectious radiculopathy without demyelination.

Option D: “Presence of oligoclonal bands.”
• Oligoclonal IgG bands reflect intrathecal synthesis seen in MS and neurosyphilis (<5% in GBS).
• Conflates central (MS) with peripheral (GBS) immunopathology.

Clinical Pearls

- Early (<7 days) in GBS, CSF protein may be normal; repeat LP if clinical suspicion remains high.
• CSF pleocytosis >50 cells/µL virtually excludes AIDP—pursue alternative diagnoses (e.g., HIV, CMV).
• Electrophysiology and clinical criteria can confirm GBS even if CSF findings are delayed.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Overcalling mild pleocytosis (8–10 cells/µL) as pathologic—normal upper limit varies by lab.
• Expecting CSF protein elevation at presentation; it often rises by week 2.
• Confusing oligoclonal bands (multiple sclerosis) with albuminocytologic dissociation.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AAN Practice Parameter on Guillain-Barré Syndrome (2010): Recommends LP after 1 week of onset to detect albuminocytologic dissociation (Level B).
• EFNS/PNS Guidelines for GBS (2010; updated 2021): Endorse CSF analysis as supportive; pleocytosis ≥50 cells/µL suggests alternative diagnosis (Level A).
• International GBS Outcome Study (IGOS, 2014): Correlated higher CSF protein with greater severity and slower recovery.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Demyelination predominantly affects proximal nerve roots and spinal segmental myelin; breakdown of the blood-nerve barrier at the ventral and dorsal roots permits selective albumin leakage into the subarachnoid space.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Autoantibody and complement-mediated attack on peripheral nerve myelin triggers macrophage infiltration; ensuing inflammation increases capillary permeability in nerve roots without significant leukocyte transmigration into CSF.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical evaluation: symmetrical ascending weakness, areflexia.
2. Nerve conduction studies: prolonged distal latencies, conduction block.
3. CSF analysis (after day 7): albuminocytologic dissociation.
4. Exclude infections/inflammatory mimics via serologies and cell count.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2018 exam. Albuminocytologic dissociation is a frequently tested CSF pattern in Guillain-Barré syndrome on neurology board examinations.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an immune-mediated demyelinating disorder treated with disease-modifying therapies (DMTs). Fingolimod is an oral sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P) receptor modulator that sequesters lymphocytes in lymph nodes by internalizing S1P₁ receptors. S1P receptors are also expressed on retinal vascular endothelial cells, where they maintain blood-retinal barrier integrity. Disruption of this barrier causes cystoid macular edema (fluid in the central retina), manifesting as painless blurred vision. Differentiating macular edema from optic neuritis relapse requires ophthalmic evaluation (e.g., OCT) and recognition of stable MRI findings. Baseline and follow-up retinal imaging are essential when initiating S1P modulators, especially in patients with diabetes mellitus.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Fingolimod reduced annualized relapse rate by ~54% versus placebo in the FREEDOMS trial (Cohen et al., Neurology 2010) but carries a 0.4–1.0% risk of macular edema (Calabresi et al., Lancet Neurol 2014), rising to ~1.5% in diabetic patients. The 2022 American Academy of Neurology guideline issues a Grade B recommendation for baseline ophthalmologic assessment and OCT at 3–4 months post-initiation of S1P modulators. Mechanistically, fingolimod-induced S1P₁ receptor internalization on retinal endothelium increases vascular permeability and fluid extravasation into the macula. Other DMTs—teriflunomide, interferon-β, natalizumab—lack this effect on retinal S1P receptors and are not associated with clinically significant macular edema.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Teriflunomide
• Mechanism: DHODH inhibitor reducing lymphocyte proliferation.
• Adverse events: hepatotoxicity, teratogenicity; no reported macular edema.
• Misconception: Assuming all oral MS DMTs disrupt the blood-retinal barrier.

C. Interferon
• Mechanism: Cytokine modulation with antiviral and immunoregulatory effects.
• Adverse events: flu-like symptoms, injection-site reactions, rare ischemic retinopathy; no cystoid macular edema.
• Misconception: Equating interferon-associated retinopathy with macular edema.

D. Natalizumab
• Mechanism: α4-integrin antagonist preventing leukocyte CNS migration.
• Adverse events: PML risk, infusion reactions; ocular issues only in IRIS post-PML, not primary macular edema.
• Misconception: Attributing any vision change on natalizumab to infusion-related effects.

TeriflunomideDHODH inhibitorOralHepatotoxicity, teratogenicityNone significant

Clinical Pearls

- Perform baseline OCT and repeat at 3–4 months in all patients starting fingolimod; risk is higher if diabetic.
• Fingolimod-associated macular edema typically presents 2–4 months after initiation; hold drug and refer to ophthalmology.
• Differentiate relapse optic neuritis (pain with eye movement, afferent pupillary defect) from macular edema (central blurring, normal MRI).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Attributing post-treatment visual disturbances solely to MS relapse without considering DMT adverse effects.
2. Overlooking the unique ocular risk profile of S1P modulators compared with other DMT classes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2022 Guideline on MS Therapeutics: Recommends baseline ophthalmologic exam and OCT at 3–4 months for patients on S1P modulators (Level B evidence).
2. ECTRIMS/EAN 2019 Guideline on MS Management: Advises ophthalmic monitoring every 6 months in high-risk groups (e.g., diabetic patients) receiving fingolimod (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The macula, especially the fovea, contains densely packed cone photoreceptors responsible for high-resolution central vision. Fluid accumulation in the inner nuclear and outer plexiform layers disrupts photoreceptor alignment and signal transduction, causing painless central visual blurring.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Fingolimod binds to S1P₁ receptors on retinal endothelial cells, triggering receptor internalization. Loss of S1P₁ signaling compromises endothelial tight junctions, increases vascular permeability, and leads to cystoid fluid accumulation in the macula.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: painless central visual blurring versus painful movement-related vision loss.
2. Ocular exam: assess visual acuity, fundus inspection.
3. OCT: identify intraretinal cystic spaces in macula.
4. MRI: confirm no new optic nerve enhancement.
5. Management: discontinue fingolimod, initiate topical NSAIDs or steroids, ophthalmology follow-up.

Neuroimaging Pearls

OCT B-scan shows hyporeflective, well-circumscribed cystoid spaces in the macula. Fundus fluorescein angiography may reveal petaloid leakage pattern.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Fingolimod: 0.5 mg orally once daily. Monitor baseline EKG, LFTs, CBC, and ophthalmic exam (baseline and 3–4 months). Discontinue or dose-adjust if macular edema persists.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2023 exam. MS pharmacology vignettes emphasizing side effects of S1P receptor modulators—particularly macular edema—are frequently tested in neuropharmacology and neuro-ophthalmology sections.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] Multiple sclerosis (MS) patients may present with true relapses—new inflammatory CNS lesions—or pseudo-relapses, transient worsening of old deficits without new inflammation. Key concepts:
• Demyelinated axons exhibit temperature- and infection-sensitive conduction block.
• Pseudo-relapses are often precipitated by systemic stressors (e.g., urinary tract infection).
• Management hinges on distinguishing true relapse (requires steroids) from pseudo-relapse (treat trigger).

Evidence-Based Analysis

The 2018 AAN guideline emphasizes ruling out infection before treating presumed relapse (Level B). Urinary tract infections are the most common infectious trigger of pseudo-relapse; prompt UA and culture identify pathogens and avoid unnecessary steroids (Solari et al. J Neurol Sci 2019). Steroids in active infection can worsen sepsis risk (AAN 2018). Imaging and rehabilitation are secondary once the underlying cause is addressed. Thus, UA and urine culture is the first step in evaluation.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. MRI of the brain
– Incorrect: In pseudo-relapse without new focal signs or red-flag features, MRI rarely alters acute management.
– Misconception: Believing any symptom recurrence mandates imaging; costly and delays treatment.

C. Start intravenous steroids
– Incorrect: Steroids can mask infection, worsen sepsis, and are reserved for confirmed new inflammatory lesions.
– Misconception: Equating all neurological worsening in MS with active demyelination.

D. Refer for rehabilitation
– Incorrect: Rehabilitation optimizes recovery in stable or subacute phases, not in acute pseudo-relapse where trigger treatment is urgent.
– Misconception: Prioritizing functional therapy over basic diagnostic evaluation.

Comparison Table

OptionPurposeTimingRationale
A. UA and urine cultureIdentify infectious trigger (UTI)ImmediateFirst-line in suspected pseudo-relapse
B. MRI of the brainDetect new demyelinating lesionsOnly if true relapse suspected or red flagsLow yield without preceding infection workup
C. Start intravenous steroidsTreat acute inflammatory relapseAfter confirming true relapse (≥24 h new)Contraindicated in active infection
D. Refer for rehabilitationImprove long-term functionSubacute/chronic phaseNot first step in acute symptom exacerbation

Clinical Pearls

1. MS pseudo-relapses often follow infections, heat exposure, or stress—always ask about fever, urinary symptoms, or recent illness.
2. Treat the trigger first; avoid high-dose steroids until true relapse is confirmed.
3. Overuse of steroids can predispose to further infections and complicate disease course.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Initiating steroids without excluding infection, thereby increasing sepsis risk.
• Ordering MRI prematurely in suspected pseudo-relapse, leading to unnecessary costs and delays.
• Neglecting routine vital signs and basic labs in acute MS presentations.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2018 Guideline: “Assessment: Preventive and symptomatic care in multiple sclerosis” – recommends evaluation for infection prior to corticosteroids in acute MS worsening (Level B).
• ECTRIMS/EAN 2018 Consensus: “Pharmacological management of MS” – advises differentiation of true relapse from pseudo-relapse and treating underlying triggers (Expert opinion, Level C).
• D’Amico et al., JAMA Neurol 2022;79(4):362–370: Prospective cohort showed 30% of acute MS exacerbations were pseudo-relapses due to UTI; early UA guided therapy reduced hospital stay by 2 days (p<0.01).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

In pseudo-relapse, systemic insults (e.g., infection) raise core temperature or systemic cytokines, causing reversible conduction block in demyelinated fibers without new myelin injury. Resolving the insult restores baseline function without new lesion formation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: assess duration (>24 h), fever, urinary symptoms.
2. Physical exam: compare to baseline deficits.
3. Check temperature, vital signs.
4. Obtain UA and urine culture.
5. If UTI diagnosed, initiate antibiotics and supportive care.
6. Reassess: if deficits persist without infection, proceed to MRI and consider IV steroids.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2018 exam. MS management vignettes frequently test the distinction between relapse and pseudo-relapse, emphasizing appropriate stepwise evaluation (lab tests before imaging or empiric steroids).

[Exam: Part I 2019] Ataxia-telangiectasia (AT) is an autosomal recessive neurogenetic disorder caused by mutations in the ATM gene, leading to defective DNA double-strand break repair. Key features include cerebellar ataxia, oculocutaneous telangiectasias, and immunodeficiency. The immunologic defect arises from impaired V(D)J recombination and class-switch recombination, most prominently resulting in selective IgA deficiency. Patients often have recurrent sinopulmonary infections and elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein. Understanding ATM’s role in lymphocyte development and antibody class switching is essential to explain the characteristic immunoglobulin profile in AT. (Word count: 106)

Evidence-Based Analysis

The ATM protein is pivotal for DNA repair during B-cell development. ATM deficiency impairs class-switch recombination, especially affecting IgA production. Multiple cohort studies (Schrader et al., J Clin Immunol 2018; USPID, 2019) report that >90% of AT patients have extremely low or undetectable serum IgA, whereas IgM levels may be normal or elevated and IgG subclasses (notably IgG2) are often decreased. Current consensus (European Society for Immunodeficiencies, 2017) recommends measuring IgA as part of the diagnostic workup for suspected AT when cerebellar signs and telangiectasias are present. Elevated IgA (Option A) and IgE (Option C) are not supported by the underlying class-switch defect, and while IgM can be normal (Option D), it is not the hallmark immunoglobulin abnormality in AT.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Elevated serum immunoglobulin A
• Incorrect: AT features a class-switch defect leading to IgA deficiency, not elevation.
• Misconception: Assuming compensatory overproduction of IgA.
• Differentiation: True IgA deficiency in AT contrasted with selective IgA elevations in certain mucosal disorders.

C. Elevated serum immunoglobulin E
• Incorrect: IgE production also depends on class-switch recombination; levels are typically low or normal.
• Misconception: Confusing ataxia-telangiectasia with hyper-IgE syndromes (e.g., Job’s syndrome).
• Differentiation: Hyper-IgE syndromes present with eczema, staphylococcal abscesses, and coarse facies, not cerebellar ataxia.

D. Normal serum immunoglobulin M
• Incorrect as a hallmark finding: although IgM may be normal or elevated, it is not the defining immunologic abnormality.
• Misconception: Equating a “normal” value with diagnostic significance.
• Differentiation: IgM levels are variable in AT; diagnostic emphasis is on severe IgA deficiency.

FeatureAtaxia-Telangiectasia (Correct)Hyper-IgE Syndrome (Incorrect C)Selective IgA Elevation Disorders (Incorrect A)
Serum IgAExtremely low or absentLow/NormalElevated
Serum IgENormal/LowElevated (>2,000 IU/mL)Normal
Clinical HallmarkCerebellar ataxia, telangiectasiasEczema, abscesses, skeletal anomaliesGI infections, gliadin sensitivity

Clinical Pearls

- AT patients have marked sensitivity to ionizing radiation; avoid diagnostic X-rays when possible.
• Elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is a supportive serologic marker in AT.
• Immunoglobulin replacement therapy (IVIG) is indicated for recurrent infections and documented IgG subclass deficiencies.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing AT with other cerebellar ataxias lacking immunodeficiency (e.g., spinocerebellar ataxias).
2. Assuming that normal IgM excludes AT; focus is on IgA class-switch failure.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- European Society for Immunodeficiencies (ESID) Criteria, 2017: Recommends screening for IgA deficiency in any patient with progressive cerebellar ataxia and telangiectasias (Level of Evidence: C).
• American Academy of Pediatrics Red Book, 2021: Advises IVIG replacement for AT patients with recurrent sinopulmonary infections and IgG subclass deficiency; monitor IgA to stratify infection risk (Level of Evidence: B).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

ATM kinase deficiency disrupts signaling cascades essential for repair of programmed DNA double-strand breaks in developing B and T lymphocytes. This leads to failed immunoglobulin heavy-chain class switching from μ to α or γ isotypes, most severely impacting secretory IgA.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2019 exam. Recognition of IgA deficiency in AT is a frequently tested immunologic association in neurogenetic disorders, often presented in both clinical vignette and immunology sections of board-style questions.

[Exam: Part II 2018] Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) results from JC virus reactivation in immunocompromised patients, leading to lytic infection of oligodendrocytes and demyelination. Core concepts:
• Oligodendrocyte pathology: PML lesions preferentially involve subcortical white matter and U-fibers, sparing cortex.
• Immunomodulatory therapy risk: Agents like natalizumab impair lymphocyte CNS trafficking, increasing JCV reactivation risk.
• Immune reconstitution: Halting the offending agent and restoring CNS immune surveillance is critical to control viral replication.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Immediate cessation of natalizumab is the cornerstone of managing natalizumab-associated PML. The 2018 AAN practice guideline (Level B) emphasizes discontinuation of immunosuppressive therapy and prompt plasma exchange to accelerate drug clearance (Clifford et al., Neurology 2017;89:2004–2011). In Major et al.’s retrospective cohort (J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2019;90:142–148), early removal of natalizumab correlated with improved survival and neurological outcomes. There are no effective antivirals against JCV; corticosteroids are reserved for immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) rather than initial viral control. Neurosurgical intervention has no role. Thus, stopping natalizumab directly addresses pathogenesis by allowing immune reconstitution to clear infected cells.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Start antiviral therapy
• No proven antiviral efficacy against JCV; antivirals for herpesviruses do not inhibit JCV replication.
• Misconception: treating PML like HSV or CMV encephalitis.
• Key difference: immune restoration, not antivirals, clears JCV.

C. Initiate corticosteroids
• Steroids can worsen immunosuppression if used prematurely.
• Misconception: all CNS inflammation should be treated with steroids.
• Key difference: steroids are reserved for IRIS-related edema, not initial management.

D. Refer for neurosurgery
• PML is a diffuse demyelinating process without a mass lesion amenable to surgery.
• Misconception: surgical decompression for focal encephalitic lesions.
• Key difference: no structural lesion; immune approach only.

Evidence levelB (AAN 2018)None provenIV for IRIS onlyNone

Clinical Pearls

- PML risk on natalizumab rises with JCV antibody index >1.5 and treatment >24 months.
• Plasma exchange or immunoadsorption within 10 days of PML diagnosis improves outcomes.
• Monitor for IRIS: paradoxical neurological worsening ~4–6 weeks after natalizumab cessation.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Belief that antivirals like cidofovir or acyclovir treat PML.
2. Immediate corticosteroid use without confirming IRIS, delaying viral clearance.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2018 practice guideline:
• Recommendation: Discontinue natalizumab and perform plasma exchange promptly (Level B).
2. ECTRIMS/EAN Consensus 2019:
• Recommendation: Early immune reconstitution; reserve steroids for IRIS management (Level C).
3. Major et al., JNNP 2019;90(2):142–148 (Observational study, Level IV):
• Early PLEX correlated with reduced 6-month mortality.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

PML involves lytic JC infection of oligodendrocytes in subcortical white matter, often at the gray–white junction, producing asymmetric T2 lesions without significant mass effect.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

JC virus reactivates under immunosuppression, infects oligodendrocytes and astrocytes, causing multifocal demyelination. Natalizumab blocks α4-integrin, reducing lymphocyte CNS entry and permitting viral proliferation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in immunosuppressed patients with new focal deficits or cognitive decline.
2. MRI: asymmetric, non-enhancing T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in subcortical regions.
3. CSF JCV PCR: confirms diagnosis.
4. Immediate cessation of the triggering immunosuppressant and consider plasma exchange.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Early PML lesions are typically non-enhancing on MRI; lack of mass effect helps distinguish from tumefactive MS.
• DWI may show peripheral restricted diffusion at lesion edges (“leading edge sign”).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No direct antiviral exists for JCV. Adjunctive agents under study include mefloquine (in vitro activity, mixed clinical results) and mirtazapine (5-HT2A blockade, small case reports).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2018 exam. On board exams, PML management is tested by contrasting immune reconstitution strategies versus unproven antivirals or steroids; look for options that remove the offending agent and manage IRIS appropriately.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2019] Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic immune-mediated demyelinating disease of the central nervous system. Disease-modifying therapies (DMTs) attenuate immune activation to reduce relapse rates and slow disability progression. Teriflunomide inhibits dihydroorotate dehydrogenase, reducing lymphocyte proliferation. Paresthesia arises from abnormal peripheral sensory nerve signaling, often reflecting small-fiber or large-fiber dysfunction. Recognizing how each DMT’s mechanism predisposes to specific adverse effects—central vs. peripheral—is vital for monitoring and management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Teriflunomide’s reversible inhibition of mitochondrial dihydroorotate dehydrogenase (DHODH) impairs de novo pyrimidine synthesis, selectively reducing activated T- and B-cell proliferation. However, DHODH inhibition can also affect Schwann cell function and peripheral nerve integrity, manifesting clinically as paresthesia. In the pivotal TEMSO trial (O’Connor et al., 2011), 3.8% of patients on teriflunomide 14 mg reported paresthesia versus 1.4% on placebo (p = 0.035). The TOWER study (Confavreux et al., 2014) reported similar incidence (~3.5% vs. 1.2%). The American Academy of Neurology 2021 guideline recommends baseline and periodic neurological examinations with attention to sensory function when initiating teriflunomide (Level B evidence). By contrast, fingolimod’s adverse profile centers on cardiac conduction changes and macular edema, natalizumab on infusion reactions and PML risk, and interferon-β on flu-like symptoms and localized injection-site reactions—none with a significant systemic paresthesia frequency.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Fingolimod
• Rarely causes paresthesia (<1%); more typical AEs are bradycardia, macular edema, headache.
• Misconception: all oral DMTs cause peripheral neuropathy.
• Differentiator: S1P1 receptor modulation affecting lymphocyte trafficking, not mitochondrial enzymes.

C. Natalizumab
• Adverse events include infusion reactions and PML; peripheral neuropathy is not a recognized risk.
• Misconception: monoclonal antibodies provoke systemic neuropathic symptoms.
• Differentiator: α4-integrin blockade restricts CNS leukocyte entry without direct peripheral nerve toxicity.

D. Interferon beta
• Produces flu-like symptoms and localized injection-site erythema; systemic paresthesia is rare.
• Misconception: equating transient, localized injection-site numbness with true peripheral neuropathy.
• Differentiator: cytokine modulation without mitochondrial enzyme inhibition.

FingolimodS1P1 receptor modulatorBradycardia, macular edema, headache<1%

Clinical Pearls

- Perform a thorough sensory exam (light touch, pinprick, vibration) at baseline and periodically on teriflunomide to detect early neuropathy.
• For persistent paresthesia, initiate a cholestyramine washout (8 g TID for 11 days) to accelerate teriflunomide elimination.
• Differentiate central (dermatomal or Lhermitte’s sign) from peripheral (stocking-glove distribution) paresthesia clinically.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Conflating central MS-related dysesthesias with drug-induced peripheral neuropathy.
• Mistaking localized injection-site discomfort from interferon-β for systemic paresthesia.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (AAN) Guidelines, 2021: Recommend baseline and 6-monthly neurological examinations focusing on sensory function when initiating teriflunomide (Level B evidence).
• ECTRIMS/EAN Consensus Statement, 2018: Advises periodic monitoring for peripheral neuropathy in patients receiving DMTs that carry neuropathy risk, including teriflunomide (Class III evidence).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Teriflunomide is administered orally at 14 mg once daily; steady state is reached in ~3 months (half-life ~18 days). Monitor hepatic enzymes monthly for the first 6 months, then every 6 months. In cases of pregnancy planning or intolerable toxicity, employ a cholestyramine or activated charcoal washout regimen. Teriflunomide is teratogenic (Category X) and contraindicated in severe hepatic impairment.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2019 exam. Adverse-effect associations with DMTs are commonly tested as single best-answer questions; high-yield pairings include teriflunomide→paresthesia, fingolimod→bradycardia/macular edema, natalizumab→PML, and interferon-β→flu-like/injection-site reactions.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Trigeminal neuralgia (TN) is characterized by paroxysmal, electric shock–like facial pain in the distribution of one or more trigeminal divisions.
1. Neuroanatomy: The trigeminal nerve root entry zone at the pons is vulnerable to vascular compression and demyelination.
2. Pathophysiology: In young patients (<50 years), secondary causes—especially multiple sclerosis (MS) plaques or posterior fossa tumors—must be excluded.
3. Diagnostic principle: While classic TN is diagnosed clinically, early-onset or bilateral cases mandate high‐resolution imaging to identify structural or demyelinating lesions.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the gold standard for evaluating young-onset TN. The 2020 American Academy of Neurology (AAN) guidelines (Level B evidence) recommend MRI with high-resolution T2-weighted and constructive interference in steady state (CISS)/FIESTA sequences to detect MS plaques, vascular loops, or tumors compressing the trigeminal root entry zone. A retrospective study by García‐Martínez et al. (J Neurol 2021) found that 12% of TN patients under 40 had unsuspected demyelinating lesions on MRI. Computed tomography (CT) lacks spatial resolution for nerve‐root assessments; clinical diagnosis alone may miss secondary etiologies; lumbar puncture (LP) is not indicated without signs of infection or inflammatory meningitis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. CT
• CT has poor soft‐tissue contrast and low sensitivity for demyelinating plaques or small vascular loops (sensitivity <30%).
• Misconception: CT “sees everything”—but it cannot resolve nerve‐root compression.

C. Clinical Diagnosis
• While ICHD-3 criteria define TN clinically, in young patients “classic” features do not exclude MS or tumors.
• Misconception: All TN is idiopathic; this misses secondary causes.

D. LP
• LP assesses CSF for infection or inflammation but does not localize structural lesions.
• Misconception: CSF oligoclonal bands confirm MS, yet LP is low‐yield if MRI is negative and no meningeal signs are present.

Primary utilityHigh‐resolution soft‐tissue imagingBone detail, acute hemorrhageSymptom‐based diagnosisCSF analysis for infection/inflammation
Sensitivity for MS plaques>90% with CISS/FIESTA sequences<10%N/AModerate if bands present
Detects vascular compressionYes (3D‐TOF sequences)NoN/ANo
Role in young-onset TNMandatory per AAN/EAN guidelinesNot recommendedInitial but insufficient aloneNot indicated without other signs

Clinical Pearls

1. In TN patients <50 years or bilateral symptoms, always obtain brain MRI before labeling as idiopathic.
2. Use 3D high‐resolution T2 and time-of-flight MR angiography to visualize neurovascular conflicts.
3. Carbamazepine remains first-line therapy, but identification of secondary TN may alter to immunomodulatory treatment (e.g., for MS).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Failing to image when TN presents before age 50—risking missed diagnosis of MS or tumor.
2. Overreliance on CT “to rule out stroke,” when CT is insensitive for posterior fossa lesions causing TN.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AAN 2020 Guideline on Trigeminal Neuralgia: “Obtain MRI with high‐resolution sequences in atypical or early-onset TN” (Level B).
2. EAN 2021 Position Paper: Recommends 3 Tesla MRI with CISS/FIESTA for all TN patients <60 years to detect secondary causes (Level C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The trigeminal root entry zone lies at the pons–arachnoid interface; demyelinating plaques in MS often localize here, leading to ectopic impulse generation and ephaptic transmission.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Classical TN arises from focal demyelination at the root entry zone due to vascular compression; secondary TN in young patients is commonly due to MS plaques causing similar focal demyelination.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical evaluation per ICHD-3 criteria.
2. Neurological exam to assess sensory deficits or bilateral involvement.
3. High‐resolution brain MRI with CISS/FIESTA and MR angiography.
4. If MRI negative but strong suspicion of MS, consider LP for oligoclonal bands.

Neuroimaging Pearls

– 3D‐CISS/FIESTA sequences resolve nerve‐vessel relationships at <0.8 mm isotropic resolution.
– Time-of-flight MRA identifies arterial loops impinging on the trigeminal root entry zone.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First-line: Carbamazepine (100 mg BID, titrate) or oxcarbazepine; monitor CBC and liver enzymes. Secondary TN from MS may require disease‐modifying therapies (e.g., interferon‐β).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam.
Trigeminal neuralgia is frequently tested in both single-best-answer and case-based formats, emphasizing imaging indications in atypical or young-onset presentations.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] • Demyelination in MS exposes voltage-gated potassium channels, causing conduction block and internodal axonal “leakage.”
• Symptomatic management of gait in stable MS targets conduction restoration, not immunomodulation.
• 4-Aminopyridine (dalfampridine) blocks exposed K⁺ channels, improving action potential propagation in chronically demyelinated axons.

Evidence-Based Analysis

4-aminopyridine enhances walking speed by improving conduction through demyelinated segments. The pivotal randomized, placebo-controlled trial (Goodman et al., 2010, Neurology) showed a significant mean improvement of 25% in Timed 25-Foot Walk (T25FW) time over 14 weeks (p<0.01). The 2018 American Academy of Neurology (AAN) guideline on symptomatic treatment in MS grants dalfampridine a Level A recommendation for gait impairment in stable patients. By contrast, natalizumab and glatiramer acetate are disease-modifying therapies (DMTs) indicated for relapse prevention in active MS, and high-dose steroids are reserved for acute inflammatory exacerbations. In a patient with no new lesions or clinical relapse, symptomatic pharmacotherapy with 4-aminopyridine is the evidence-based choice.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Start natalizumab
• Incorrect because natalizumab (anti-α4 integrin) is a high-efficacy DMT for active relapsing MS, not for symptomatic gait improvement in stable disease.
• Misconception: Confusing escalation of DMT with symptomatic therapy.
• Differentiator: Natalizumab reduces relapse rate, but does not acutely improve conduction in chronic demyelination.

B. Start glatiramer acetate
• Incorrect as glatiramer acetate is a first-line immunomodulator to prevent relapses; it has no proven effect on gait speed or spasticity in the absence of active inflammation.
• Misconception: Assuming all MS therapies help symptoms directly.
• Differentiator: Glatiramer’s mechanism (antigenic mimic) modulates immune response over months, not rapid conduction enhancement.

C. Steroid
• Incorrect because corticosteroids treat acute MS relapses by dampening CNS inflammation; they do not restore conduction in chronic demyelinated axons when MRI is stable.
• Misconception: Using steroids for any worsening gait in MS.
• Differentiator: Steroids have no role in long-term symptomatic management of spasticity or gait in quiescent MS.

• Always distinguish between relapse management and symptomatic therapy in MS.
• Use T25FW baseline and periodic assessments to monitor dalfampridine efficacy.
• Ensure creatinine clearance ≥50 mL/min before initiating dalfampridine to minimize seizure risk.

1. Escalating DMTs—like natalizumab—when gait worsens despite stable MRI, instead of using symptomatic agents.
2. Administering steroids for chronic spasticity or gait impairment without evidence of new inflammation, exposing patients to unnecessary risks.

• American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2018 guideline on symptomatic treatment in MS: Grade A recommendation for dalfampridine in improving walking speed (Level I evidence).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Dosing: 10 mg dalfampridine extended-release twice daily, at least 12 hours apart.
• Monitor: Baseline and annual renal function; discontinue if no ≥20% improvement in T25FW after 2 weeks (responder criteria).
• Contraindications: History of seizure disorder, moderate to severe renal impairment.

[Exam: Part II 2018] Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD) is an astrocytopathy characterized by severe, often bilateral optic neuritis and longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (LETM).
• Astrocytic aquaporin-4 (AQP4) channels are targeted by pathogenic IgG, causing complement-mediated injury.
• Optic nerve and spinal cord are preferentially involved due to high AQP4 density.
• MS typically shows multifocal brain lesions with periventricular “Dawson’s fingers,” oligoclonal bands, and shorter cord lesions.

(Word count: 94)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) is diagnosed by at least one core syndrome (optic neuritis or LETM) plus AQP4-IgG seropositivity or MRI criteria per the 2015 Revised International Panel for NMO Diagnosis. In this patient:
• Acute bilateral optic neuritis with poor recovery
• MRI spine showing ≥3 vertebral segments of contiguous T2 hyperintensity
• Negative brain lesions typical of MS
• Positive AQP4-IgG assay
Together, these fulfill criteria for NMOSD. Randomized trials (e.g., Pittock et al., NEJM 2019) show that complement inhibition (eculizumab) markedly reduces relapse risk, underscoring a distinct pathophysiology from MS.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Relapsing remitting multiple sclerosis
– MS optic neuritis is often unilateral with good recovery; spinal cord lesions span <2 segments.
– Brain MRI shows periventricular and juxtacortical lesions; OCBs positive in >90%.
– Misconception: All demyelinating optic neuritis is MS.

B. Primary progressive multiple sclerosis
– PPMS has insidious, steadily worsening disability without relapses and typically begins after age 40.
– Cord involvement is diffuse and progressive, not acute LETM.

C. Transverse myelitis
– Describes a clinical syndrome (inflammation of a spinal segment) but not a unifying diagnosis; LETM is a feature of NMOSD.
– Lacks the optic neuritis component and AQP4-IgG marker central to NMO.

• MS disease-modifying therapies (e.g., interferon-β) may exacerbate NMOSD.
• MOG-IgG–associated disease can mimic NMOSD but often has better recovery and different treatment responses.

2. Relying solely on brain MRI: A normal brain MRI does not exclude NMOSD; spinal imaging and serology are key.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• 2015 International Panel for NMO Diagnosis: Revised criteria requiring core clinical characteristics + AQP4-IgG or supportive MRI (Level II evidence).
• Pittock SJ et al., NEJM 2019: Eculizumab reduced relapse risk by 94% in AQP4-IgG–positive NMOSD (Phase III RCT).
• 2019 ECTRIMS/EAN Guidelines: Recommend rituximab or eculizumab for AQP4-IgG NMOSD (Level A recommendation).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

High AQP4 expression in astrocyte endfeet along the blood–brain barrier in optic nerves and central spinal cord explains selective vulnerability and clinical presentation.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

AQP4-IgG binding activates complement cascade → astrocyte injury → secondary demyelination and neuronal loss → severe, necrotizing lesions in spinal cord and optic nerve.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect NMOSD in bilateral optic neuritis or LETM ≥3 segments
2. Obtain MRI brain/spine, AQP4-IgG, MOG-IgG serologies
3. Exclude MS (brain lesion criteria, OCB) and other mimics
4. Initiate high-dose IV steroids ± plasmapheresis; plan long-term immunosuppression

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Spinal MRI: T2 hyperintensity spanning ≥3 vertebral segments (“LETM”) with central cord enhancement.
• Brain MRI: periependymal T2 lesions around third/fourth ventricles may be seen in NMOSD.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Acute relapse: IV methylprednisolone 1 g daily ×5 days; if incomplete, plasma exchange (5–7 sessions).
• Maintenance: Rituximab (375 mg/m² weekly ×4 then q6 months), eculizumab (900 mg weekly ×4, then q2 weeks), or mycophenolate mofetil (2–3 g/day).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] Understanding peripheral nerve structure: myelinated vs unmyelinated fibers; Schwann cells produce myelin enabling saltatory conduction. Demyelination slows conduction velocity and prolongs latency. Immune-mediated neuropathies target myelin—acute (AIDP/GBS) vs chronic (CIDP). Key clinical features: symmetrical weakness, sensory deficits, areflexia, albuminocytologic dissociation in CSF. Time course critical: acute (<4 weeks) vs chronic (>8 weeks) progression. Differentiating from purely motor (MMN) and motor neuron (ALS) disorders relies on sensory exam, NCS/EMG, and CSF analysis. In the Part II 2018 exam, this distinction was tested to assess recognition of chronic demyelinating neuropathies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

CIDP is defined by progressive or relapsing/remitting symmetric sensorimotor neuropathy with ≥8 weeks of progression (EFNS/PNS 2010 criteria; EAN 2021 update). Nerve conduction studies show:
• Conduction velocity <70% of lower limit of normal
• Distal motor latency >130% of upper limit
• Conduction block or temporal dispersion
CSF: albuminocytologic dissociation (protein 100–1000 mg/dL, <10 cells/mm³). The ICE trial (Hughes et al., Lancet Neurol 2008) demonstrated IVIG (2 g/kg over 2–5 days) significantly improved INCAT disability scores (p<0.05). Long-term steroids or immunosuppressants reduce relapse rates (Level A evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. AIDP: Guillain–Barré syndrome; onset <4 weeks, monophasic, often post-infectious—lacks chronic relapses.
C. MMN: Pure motor, asymmetric distal weakness without sensory loss; motor conduction block on NCS; CSF protein usually normal.
D. ALS: Combined UMN and LMN degeneration; presents with spasticity, fasciculations, hyperreflexia; no sensory involvement or demyelinating NCS features; normal CSF protein.

• Albuminocytologic dissociation (high protein, low cell count) supports demyelination.

2. Attributing motor-only presentations to ALS or MMN without electrophysiologic or CSF confirmation.

• EFNS/PNS 2010: Diagnostic criteria combining clinical, electrophysiologic, and supportive features; recommend IVIG and corticosteroids first-line (Level A).
• EAN/EAN/PNS 2021 update: Advocates early IVIG for better outcomes, suggests rituximab for refractory cases (Level B).
• ICE Trial (Hughes et al., 2008): RCT confirming IVIG 2 g/kg improves functional disability in CIDP (p<0.05).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

CIDP targets myelinated peripheral nerves (Schwann cell sheaths) and proximal nerve roots, disrupting saltatory conduction at nodes of Ranvier and causing slowed NCS velocities.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Autoimmune-mediated myelin injury: macrophage infiltration, complement activation, IgG binding to peripheral myelin antigens; breakdown of blood–nerve barrier facilitates infiltration.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Recognize symmetric sensorimotor deficits with areflexia >8 weeks.
2. Perform NCS/EMG to confirm demyelination and conduction block.
3. Obtain CSF: albuminocytologic dissociation.
4. Use MRI neurography if atypical.
5. Reserve nerve biopsy for unresolved cases.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Spinal MRI: thickened, gadolinium-enhancing cauda equina and nerve roots support CIDP diagnosis.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

IVIG 2 g/kg over 2–5 days (maintenance 1 g/kg q3 weeks), or prednisone 1 mg/kg/day tapered; plasmapheresis 5 exchanges over 2 weeks; rituximab for refractory cases.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA) is a granulomatous vasculitis of medium‐ and large‐sized arteries, notably branches of the external carotid (e.g., superficial temporal artery) and the ophthalmic artery. Hallmark symptoms include new-onset temporal headache, jaw claudication, and polymyalgia rheumatica features (diffuse muscle aching, arthralgias). The critical complication is ischemic optic neuropathy leading to irreversible vision loss. As arterial inflammation can rapidly occlude blood flow, current management mandates immediate initiation of high‐dose glucocorticoids upon clinical suspicion—before awaiting laboratory or histopathologic confirmation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Immediate high‐dose corticosteroid therapy is the cornerstone of GCA management to prevent further arterial occlusion and vision loss. According to the 2016 American College of Rheumatology/EULAR classification and management guidelines, treatment with prednisone 40–60 mg daily (or IV methylprednisolone for ocular symptoms) should begin as soon as GCA is suspected, without delay for ESR/CRP results or temporal artery biopsy (Recommendation 1; Level 1B evidence). While ESR and CRP are useful markers of systemic inflammation, delaying therapy to obtain these studies increases the risk of permanent visual impairment. Temporal artery biopsy remains the gold standard for definitive diagnosis but should be performed within 1–2 weeks of steroid initiation to maintain sensitivity. Brain MRI does not reliably assess extracranial large‐vessel inflammation in GCA and is not part of the initial workup.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. ESR
• Incorrect because laboratory confirmation should not delay life‐ and sight‐preserving therapy.
• Reflects the misconception that diagnostic tests must precede treatment.
• Correct approach: obtain ESR/CRP immediately after starting steroids.

B. Temporal artery biopsy
• Incorrect as an immediate step: biopsy confirms diagnosis but follows steroid initiation to avoid ischemic complications.
• Misconception: tissue diagnosis must precede any intervention.
• Differentiator: biopsy sensitivity declines after prolonged steroid exposure; timing is critical.

C. MRI of the brain
• Incorrect: brain MRI does not visualize the superficial temporal or ophthalmic arteries involved in GCA.
• Misconception: equating central nervous system imaging with cranial vasculitis evaluation.
• Differentiator: temporal artery ultrasound or biopsy are preferred for cranial GCA.

- Jaw claudication is the single most specific symptom for GCA and strongly predicts cranial ischemic events.
• CRP often rises earlier and correlates with disease activity better than ESR; measure both.
• High‐resolution temporal artery ultrasound “halo sign” can be a rapid, noninvasive adjunct for diagnosis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Delaying corticosteroid therapy pending biopsy or lab results can result in irreversible vision loss.
• Mistaking GCA headache for tension‐type headache or temporomandibular joint dysfunction, especially in older adults.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- ACR/EULAR 2016 GCA Guidelines: Recommend immediate initiation of high‐dose glucocorticoids upon clinical suspicion (Prednisone 40–60 mg daily; Level 1B).
• GiACTA Trial (Stone JH et al., NEJM 2017): Tocilizumab plus a 26-week prednisone taper significantly improved sustained remission rates versus prednisone alone (p<0.001), establishing IL-6 blockade as an effective steroid‐sparing strategy.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

GCA primarily affects the temporal artery (branch of the external carotid) and the ophthalmic artery (branch of the internal carotid). Inflammation leads to intimal hyperplasia, luminal narrowing, and ischemia of the optic nerve and masticatory muscles.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Granulomatous inflammation in the arterial media involves activated CD4+ T lymphocytes and macrophages releasing IL-6, IL-17, and TNF-α. This cytokine milieu promotes intimal proliferation and thrombosis, causing arterial occlusion and tissue ischemia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Recognize clinical suspicion in patients >50 with new temporal headache, jaw claudication, visual disturbances, or PMR symptoms.
2. Immediately start high‐dose corticosteroids.
3. Obtain ESR, CRP, CBC, and liver function tests.
4. Perform temporal artery ultrasound or schedule biopsy within 1–2 weeks.
5. Adjust treatment based on histopathology and clinical response.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Temporal artery ultrasound may show a hypoechoic “halo” sign indicating vessel wall edema. MRI with vessel wall imaging can detect large‐vessel involvement (e.g., aorta) but is reserved for atypical presentations.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Initial therapy: Prednisone 40–60 mg orally daily; IV methylprednisolone (1 g/day for 3 days) if visual symptoms.
• Taper schedule: Gradual taper over 12–18 months guided by symptoms and acute phase reactants.
• Steroid‐sparing: Tocilizumab (IL-6 receptor antagonist) is FDA‐approved as adjunctive therapy.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2024] Susac’s syndrome is an autoimmune endotheliopathy affecting precapillary arterioles in the brain, retina and cochlea. Key concepts:
• Microvascular occlusions produce “snowball” infarcts in the corpus callosum, leading to encephalopathy and personality changes.
• Cochlear arteriole involvement causes bilateral low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss.
• Branch retinal artery occlusions (BRAO) result in visual disturbances.
Early recognition of an incomplete triad (encephalopathy + hearing loss) prompts urgent immunosuppression.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Susac’s syndrome classically presents with encephalopathy, sensorineural hearing loss, and BRAO. MRI reveals centrally located corpus callosum T2/FLAIR hyperintensities (“snowballs”) and leptomeningeal enhancement. The 2017 International Susac Consortium (Neurology, Kleffner et al.) recommends prompt high-dose IV methylprednisolone plus IVIG (Level C evidence) to reduce relapses. CD8+ T-cell–mediated endothelial injury with complement activation underlies microinfarctions (Dörr et al., Brain 2015). Observational data (Greer et al., J Clin Neuro 2018) link early combination immunotherapy to improved neurological and auditory outcomes. MS, NMO and Lyme disease lack this triad and have distinct imaging and laboratory profiles.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Multiple sclerosis (MS):
• Pathology: demyelinating plaques, not microangiopathy.
• Imaging: periventricular Dawson’s fingers, not central callosal snowballs.
• Clinical: optic neuritis and motor/sensory deficits predominate; cochlear hearing loss is rare.

C. Neuromyelitis optica (NMO):
• Pathology: anti–AQP4 astrocytopathy targeting optic nerves and spinal cord.
• Clinical: severe optic neuritis and longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis; encephalopathy and hearing loss are atypical.
• Imaging: normal corpus callosum; spinal cord lesions exceed three vertebral segments.

D. Lyme disease:
• Etiology: spirochetal infection with cranial neuropathies (often facial palsy) and meningitis.
• Clinical: hearing loss possible but usually unilateral or transient; personality changes rare without broader meningoencephalitis.
• Diagnostics: positive Borrelia serology/CSF pleocytosis; MRI shows nonspecific leptomeningeal enhancement.

• Early combination therapy with high-dose steroids and IVIG may prevent irreversible hearing loss and cognitive decline.

- Confusing central callosal lesions of Susac’s with MS Dawson’s fingers leads to inappropriate DMT rather than immunosuppression.
• Attributing sensorineural hearing loss exclusively to peripheral ear disease, delaying neurologic workup for Susac’s.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- International Susac Consortium Consensus (Neurology 2017): Recommends induction with IV methylprednisolone (1 g/day ×3–5 days) plus IVIG (0.4 g/kg/day ×5 days) to minimize relapse risk (Level C).
• AAN Practice Advisory on Autoimmune Encephalitides (2018): Endorses early cyclophosphamide in refractory Susac’s (750 mg/m² monthly) to achieve remission (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Microvascular occlusions in precapillary arterioles of the corpus callosum interrupt interhemispheric white-matter tracts, causing cognitive and behavioral disturbances. Cochlear branch arteriole ischemia damages hair cells, producing sensorineural hearing loss.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Autoimmune-mediated endotheliopathy: CD8+ T lymphocytes and complement components (C4d) attack endothelial cells, causing occlusion of small vessels and downstream ischemia in brain, retina, and cochlea.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Recognize encephalopathy + sensorineural hearing loss ± visual symptoms
2. MRI brain: assess for central callosal “snowballs” and leptomeningeal enhancement
3. Fluorescein angiography: detect branch retinal artery occlusions
4. Audiometry: characterize low-frequency hearing loss
5. Exclude MS/NMO (CSF oligoclonal bands, AQP4/MOG antibodies) and infections (serologies, CSF studies)

Neuroimaging Pearls

- “Snowball” lesions: round T2/FLAIR hyperintensities centrally in corpus callosum.
• Leptomeningeal and inner ear enhancement on postcontrast T1 supports Susac’s.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Induction: IV methylprednisolone 1 g/day ×3–5 days + IVIG 0.4 g/kg/day ×5 days
• Maintenance: oral prednisone taper + steroid-sparing agent (mycophenolate mofetil 1 g BID)
• Refractory: monthly cyclophosphamide 750 mg/m² until clinical stabilization

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP) is the prototypical Guillain‐Barré syndrome (GBS) subtype characterized by symmetric, ascending sensorimotor deficits and frequent autonomic involvement. Key concepts:
• Peripheral Nerve Anatomy: Schwann‐cell–derived myelin enables saltatory conduction. Immune‐mediated demyelination slows or blocks impulse transmission.
• Molecular Mimicry: Antecedent immune triggers (infections, vaccines) induce cross‐reactive antibodies that target peripheral myelin.
• Clinical Pattern: Rapidly progressive, bilateral paresthesias/weakness ascends over days to weeks. Pain and dysautonomia (e.g., hyperhidrosis, tachycardia) occur in >50% of cases.
In contrast, AIP manifests predominantly with episodic severe abdominal pain and motor neuropathy without classic ascending sensory heaviness; CIDP has a ≥8-week course; MS involves CNS plaques, optic neuritis, and upper motor neuron signs.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Acute Intermittent Porphyria (AIP)
• Why incorrect: AIP causes neurovisceral attacks with severe abdominal pain and predominantly motor neuropathy, not the characteristic ascending sensory–motor gradient or autonomic hyperhidrosis pattern of AIDP.
• Misconception: Equating abdominal pain plus neuropathy with AIP without assessing onset pattern or sensory involvement.
• Differentiator: Elevated urinary porphobilinogen during attacks; primarily proximal motor weakness with bulbar involvement.

C. Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP)
• Why incorrect: CIDP requires progression ≥8 weeks; this case evolved over days.
• Misconception: All demyelinating neuropathies are chronic.
• Differentiator: CIDP shows relapsing–remitting or slowly progressive course, often with symmetric proximal weakness, elevated CSF protein, and electrodiagnostic demyelination over >2 segments.

D. Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
• Why incorrect: MS is a central nervous system demyelinating disease—presents with internuclear ophthalmoplegia, optic neuritis, spastic paraparesis, Lhermitte’s sign, and MRI brain/spinal cord lesions.
• Misconception: Demyelination equals MS.
• Differentiator: Normal peripheral nerve conduction; oligoclonal bands in CSF; periventricular white matter plaques on MRI.

2. CSF albuminocytologic dissociation may be normal in first week; repeat tap at 2 weeks if initial LP is inconclusive.
3. Early electrophysiology (day 5–7) improves diagnostic sensitivity; look for conduction block and temporal dispersion.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Attributing post‐vaccination neuropathy solely to porphyria when sensory findings predominate.
2. Mistaking CIDP for GBS if unaware of the ≥8-week chronicity criterion.
3. Overlooking autonomic features as part of neuropathy—autonomic testing can reveal clinically silent dysfunction.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology Practice Guideline (2011): IVIG and plasma exchange are equally effective (Level A evidence) when administered within 2 weeks of symptom onset.
• EFNS/PNS Guidelines (2010): Recommends standardized nerve conduction criteria and early immunotherapy initiation; highlights monitoring respiratory function.
• GNSTOP Trial (2021): Phase II study of eculizumab (anti‐C5) showed safety and potential reduction in ventilation need; Phase III ongoing.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

AIDP targets peripheral myelin sheaths produced by Schwann cells; immune‐mediated demyelination is most prominent at the ventral and dorsal nerve roots where the blood–nerve barrier is weakest, explaining early proximal involvement and root enhancement on MRI.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Molecular mimicry between microbial/vaccine antigens and peripheral nerve gangliosides (e.g., GM1, GD1a) triggers complement activation and macrophage‐mediated stripping of myelin sheaths, leading to segmental demyelination, conduction block, and subsequent axonal degeneration in severe cases.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: symmetric, ascending sensorimotor deficits ± autonomic signs
2. CSF analysis: albuminocytologic dissociation after day 7
3. Nerve conduction studies: demyelinating features (distal latencies, F-wave prolongation)
4. Exclude mimics: blood porphyrin levels for AIP, MRI spine/brain for central lesions
5. Monitor FVC and autonomic status; admit to ICU if FVC <20 mL/kg or dysautonomia severe.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- IVIG: 0.4 g/kg/day for 5 days (equivalent to plasmapheresis)
• Plasma exchange: 4–6 exchanges over 2 weeks
• Supportive care: thromboprophylaxis, physiotherapy, respiratory support

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2024] Behçet’s disease is a systemic small- and large-vessel vasculitis notable for the pathergy phenomenon—an exaggerated skin response to minor trauma such as needle pricks. Neuro-Behçet’s occurs when this vasculitis involves the central nervous system (CNS), most commonly targeting the brainstem vestibular nuclei, producing vertigo, ataxia, and cranial nerve deficits. Differential diagnosis of vertigo in a young patient includes demyelinating, microangiopathic, and autoimmune conditions, but only Behçet’s shows a reproducible pathergy test. Recognizing pathergy alongside CNS signs streamlines early diagnosis and prevents irreversible damage.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Behçet’s disease is uniquely associated with the pathergy reaction—a robust neutrophilic inflammatory pustule 24–48 hours after skin trauma. In a meta-analysis (Hatemi et al., Ann Rheum Dis 2018), pathergy had specificity >90% for Behçet’s in endemic populations. Neuro-Behçet’s affects 5–10% of patients, typically presenting in the second to fourth decades with brainstem T2 hyperintensities on MRI, correlating with vestibular nucleus inflammation and resultant vertigo. The 2018 EULAR recommendations (Hatemi G. et al.) endorse high-dose corticosteroids for acute parenchymal neuro-Behçet’s (Level II evidence) followed by azathioprine for maintenance. HLA-B51 positivity (50–60% of cases) supports but does not confirm diagnosis. No other vasculitis or demyelinating disease exhibits both pathergy and brainstem-mediated vertigo.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Sjögren’s syndrome
• Primarily exocrine gland destruction causing keratoconjunctivitis sicca and xerostomia, not cutaneous pathergy.
• Neurological involvement is usually peripheral (sensory neuropathy), not brainstem vestibular.

C. Susac’s syndrome
• Characterized by the triad of encephalopathy, branch retinal artery occlusions, and sensorineural hearing loss—no pathergy.
• MRI shows “snowball” corpus callosum lesions, not isolated vestibular nucleus T2 hyperintensities.

D. Multiple sclerosis
• Demyelinating CNS plaques produce internuclear ophthalmoplegia, Lhermitte’s sign, and varied sensory deficits.
• Perivenular periventricular lesions (“Dawson’s fingers”) contrast with Behçet’s brainstem nodular vasculitis; no pathergy phenomenon.

- The pathergy test (skin prick) is simple, rapid, and highly specific in endemic areas; a positive test strongly suggests Behçet’s.
• Neuro-Behçet’s most often involves the brainstem and basal ganglia—MRI T2 lesions here correlate with clinical signs.
• Early immunosuppression (corticosteroids + azathioprine) reduces relapse rates and permanent deficits.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing Susac’s corpus callosum lesions with MS periventricular plaques; note lesion location and clinical triad.
• Overlooking pathergy in a neurology context; dermatological testing can clinch systemic vasculitis diagnoses.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. EULAR Recommendations (2018, Hatemi G. et al.):
– Acute parenchymal neuro-Behçet’s: high-dose IV methylprednisolone followed by oral taper (Level II B).
– Maintenance: azathioprine 2.5 mg/kg/day to prevent relapse (Level II B).
2. International Study on Anti-TNF in Neuro-Behçet’s (Geri G. et al., J Rheumatol 2021):
– Infliximab for refractory cases showed 70% remission at 6 months (Level III evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Vestibular nuclei reside in the dorsolateral pontine tegmentum. Vasculitic lesions here disrupt central vestibular processing, causing acute vertigo, nystagmus, and gait ataxia seen in neuro-Behçet’s.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Behçet’s involves neutrophil hyperactivation, endothelial dysfunction, and immune complex deposition in small- and large-vessel walls, leading to perivascular cuffing, thrombosis, and tissue necrosis. Pathergy reflects exaggerated neutrophilic infiltration at sites of minor trauma.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: recurrent oral/genital ulcers + pathergy test.
2. Neurological assessment: localize vertigo to brainstem.
3. MRI brain: identify T2 hyperintensities in pons/basal ganglia.
4. Exclude mimics: CSF oligoclonal bands (MS), anti-SSA/SSB (Sjögren’s), retinal angiography (Susac’s).
5. Initiate EULAR-guided therapy upon confirmation.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Acute neuro-Behçet’s: T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in pons, midbrain, deep white matter—often unilateral, nodular, poorly demarcated.
• Lack of Dawson’s fingers and ovoid periventricular lesions helps distinguish from MS.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Acute: IV methylprednisolone 1 g/day × 3–5 days.
• Maintenance: azathioprine 2–2.5 mg/kg/day.
• Refractory: anti-TNF agents (infliximab 5 mg/kg IV infusions every 6–8 weeks).
