[Exam: Part II 2018] Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD) is an astrocytopathy driven by autoantibodies against aquaporin-4 (AQP4) water channels concentrated on astrocyte endfeet, particularly in the optic nerves and spinal cord. Clinically, NMOSD presents with bilateral optic neuritis and longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (LETM ≥3 vertebral segments). Distinguishing NMOSD from multiple sclerosis (MS) is critical, as MS therapies can exacerbate NMOSD. The landmark 2015 International Panel criteria designate serum AQP4-IgG as a core diagnostic biomarker with high specificity (>99%) and moderate sensitivity. Conventional MRI, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis, and evoked potentials provide supportive yet non-definitive data. Early, accurate serological diagnosis enables prompt immunosuppression to reduce relapse risk and permanent disability.
(138 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Serological testing for AQP4-IgG using cell-based assays is the gold standard for NMOSD diagnosis. The 2015 International Panel for NMOSD Diagnosis requires at least one core clinical characteristic (optic neuritis, LETM, area postrema syndrome, etc.) plus AQP4-IgG positivity to establish NMOSD. Cell-based assays achieve sensitivity of 76–91% and specificity >99% (Jarius et al., 2018; Waters et al., 2016). False negatives occur in early disease; repeat testing is recommended if clinical suspicion remains high.
MRI of the brain in NMOSD often shows normal findings or nonspecific white matter changes, lacking the periventricular “Dawson’s fingers” of MS. Spinal MRI confirming LETM supports, but does not confirm, NMOSD. CSF analysis reveals pleocytosis (>50 cells/µL) in acute attacks and rarely oligoclonal bands (20–30%), making it nondiagnostic. Visual evoked potentials detect conduction delay but cannot distinguish NMOSD from other demyelinating conditions. Therefore, serum AQP4-IgG testing is most useful for definitive diagnosis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. MRI of the brain
• Why incorrect: Brain MRI in NMOSD may be normal or show nonspecific lesions; classic MS features (periventricular Dawson’s fingers, juxtacortical lesions) are uncommon.
• Misconception: Equating any CNS demyelination on MRI with NMOSD.
• Differentiator: MRI supports lesion localization but lacks the pathognomonic specificity of AQP4-IgG.

C. Lumbar puncture
• Why incorrect: CSF in NMOSD shows nonspecific pleocytosis and elevated protein; oligoclonal bands are present in only ~20–30%.
• Misconception: Believing CSF oligoclonal bands confirm demyelination type.
• Differentiator: CSF findings overlap with infections and other inflammatory myelopathies; AQP4-IgG directly identifies the disease mechanism.

D. Visual evoked potentials
• Why incorrect: VEP demonstrates optic nerve demyelination via P100 latency delay but cannot identify underlying etiology.
• Misconception: Assuming any optic pathway conduction abnormality confirms NMOSD.
• Differentiator: VEP is sensitive for optic neuritis but not specific for AQP4-mediated astrocyte injury.

Clinical Pearls

- LETM spanning ≥3 vertebral segments on spinal MRI is a red flag for NMOSD versus MS.
• Cell-based assays outperform ELISA in detecting conformational AQP4 epitopes; always request a cell-based assay.
• In seronegative cases, test for MOG-IgG to identify MOG-related demyelinating disease.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overreliance on CSF oligoclonal bands—these are less frequent in NMOSD than in MS, leading to false reassurance if absent.
2. Misinterpreting nonspecific brain MRI lesions as MS—absence of classic MS features should prompt AQP4-IgG testing in LETM.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- International Panel for NMOSD Diagnosis 2015: Revised criteria mandate AQP4-IgG positivity plus one core clinical characteristic for definitive NMOSD (Level C evidence).
• ECTRIMS/EAN Clinical Practice Guidelines 2018: Strongly recommend cell-based AQP4-IgG testing in all patients presenting with LETM or bilateral optic neuritis (Level B evidence).
• PREVENT Trial (Pittock et al., 2019): Demonstrated eculizumab efficacy in reducing NMOSD relapses in AQP4-IgG-positive patients, underscoring the importance of early serological diagnosis.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] B-cell lysis agents (anti-CD20 monoclonal antibodies such as rituximab and ocrelizumab) deplete circulating B lymphocytes via complement- and antibody-dependent cytotoxicity.
1. Infusion reactions are primarily cytokine-release phenomena driven by rapid B-cell destruction, leading to release of interleukins (IL-6, IL-8) and tumor necrosis factor (TNF-α).
2. These reactions occur most frequently during the first infusion when the B-cell burden is highest.
3. Subsequent doses carry a much lower risk because circulating B cells have already been depleted.
In neuroimmunology (MS, NMOSD), recognition and management of acute infusion reactions is essential to maximize safety and patient adherence.

(Word count: 120)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Flushing, throat irritation, pruritus and mild rigors constitute the most common first-dose infusion reactions with anti-CD20 therapies. In the pivotal OPERA I/II ocrelizumab trials (Hauser et al., NEJM 2017), 34–40% of patients experienced infusion reactions, predominantly grade 1–2 symptoms such as flushing and throat tightness, almost exclusively with the first infusion. The manufacturer’s prescribing information for rituximab reports infusion reactions in up to 77% of patients on first dose, decreasing to <10% on subsequent administrations. AAN practice guidelines (2018) recommend premedication with methylprednisolone 100 mg IV, diphenhydramine 50 mg PO/IV and acetaminophen to mitigate these early reactions (Level B evidence). True IgE-mediated anaphylaxis is exceedingly rare; infections and hypogammaglobulinemia are delayed effects appearing after repeated courses, not acutely on first exposure.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Anaphylaxis
• Why incorrect: True IgE-mediated reactions to fully humanized anti-CD20 antibodies are rare (<1%).
• Misconception: Equating infusion reactions with anaphylaxis; the former is cytokine-driven, not mast-cell degranulation.
• Differentiation: Anaphylaxis presents with hypotension, urticaria, bronchospasm and laryngeal edema, whereas most infusion reactions are mild, transient flushing and throat discomfort.

C. Upper respiratory infections
• Why incorrect: While recurrent infections (especially URIs) occur with chronic B-cell depletion, they are delayed – peak risk after several months of therapy.
• Misconception: Believing infectious risks manifest immediately.
• Differentiation: First-infusion reactions occur within hours; infections present days to months later.

D. Hypogammaglobulinemia
• Why incorrect: Hypogammaglobulinemia develops after prolonged B-cell suppression over multiple dosing cycles, not acutely.
• Misconception: Assuming antibody-mediated therapies instantly reduce immunoglobulin levels.
• Differentiation: Serum IgG levels decline over 6–12 months; immediate effects are infusion reactions.

Clinical Pearls

- Premedicate all first infusions of anti-CD20 agents with steroids, antihistamines and acetaminophen to reduce cytokine-release events.
• Extend infusion duration (e.g., from 2 hrs to 4 hrs) if mild reactions occur; most resolve without stopping therapy.
• Educate patients that mild flushing and throat tightness are expected and not an indication to abandon therapy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing cytokine-release reactions (grade 1–2 flushing) with true anaphylaxis, leading to unnecessary cessation of therapy.
2. Underestimating the timing: misattributing delayed infections or hypogammaglobulinemia to first infusions rather than recognizing these as long-term risks.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology (2018) Practice Guideline on DMTs in MS
• Recommendation: Pre-infusion corticosteroids and antihistamines to mitigate first-dose reactions (Level B).
2. ECTRIMS/EAN Guideline (2020) on neuroimmunological treatments
• Recommendation: Monitor vital signs every 15 minutes during infusion and extend infusion time upon mild reaction (Class II evidence).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Rituximab: 375 mg/m² IV weekly ×4 doses or 1 g IV ×2 doses separated by 2 weeks; premedicate to reduce IR.
• Ocrelizumab: 300 mg IV on days 1 & 15 for initial course, then 600 mg every 6 months; administer methylprednisolone 100 mg IV 30 minutes prior.

[Exam: Part I 2024] One-and-a-half syndrome results from a focal lesion affecting both the paramedian pontine reticular formation/abducens nucleus (causing an ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy) and the adjacent medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF; causing internuclear ophthalmoplegia). The abducens nucleus projects to the ipsilateral lateral rectus and, via interneurons through the MLF, to the contralateral oculomotor nucleus for medial rectus activation. In multiple sclerosis, demyelinating plaques commonly involve brainstem tracts such as the MLF and PPRF. Clinically, the ipsilateral eye cannot move horizontally in either direction, while the contralateral eye can abduct (often with nystagmus) but fails to adduct. Recognizing this unique pattern is critical for precise neuroanatomical localization and guides MRI evaluation and acute management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

One-and-a-half syndrome was first characterized by Fisher in 1967 and is now a classic neuro-ophthalmologic sign. The 2017 Revised McDonald Criteria (Thompson AJ et al., Lancet Neurol 2018) include brainstem lesion dissemination when diagnosing MS. High‐resolution MRI with FLAIR and gadolinium-enhanced T1 sequences typically reveals T2 hyperintense, ring‐enhancing plaques in the dorsal pontine tegmentum corresponding to clinical deficits (Lubin et al., J Neurol Sci 2008). Wingerchuk et al. (Neurology 2010) reported one-and-a-half syndrome in up to 15% of MS patients with brainstem involvement. The National MS Society 2018 guidelines recommend IV methylprednisolone 1 g daily for 3–5 days (Level A evidence) to accelerate recovery from acute demyelinating events. Accurate clinical localization minimizes diagnostic delay and avoids unnecessary investigations.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia (BINO)
• In BINO, bilateral MLF lesions impair adduction in both eyes, but abduction remains intact (often with nystagmus). There is no ipsilateral conjugate gaze palsy; both abduction movements are preserved.

B. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO)
• A unilateral MLF lesion causes failure of adduction of the ipsilateral eye with preserved abduction (with nystagmus) of the contralateral eye. There is no ipsilateral gaze palsy affecting both adduction and abduction.

D. Convergence palsy
• Convergence palsy selectively impairs medial rectus activation during convergence, while lateral gaze (abduction/adduction) remains normal. This does not produce the characteristic horizontal gaze palsy or internuclear deficit seen in one-and-a-half syndrome.

Clinical Pearls

- One-and-a-half syndrome precisely localizes to the dorsal pontine tegmentum affecting both abducens complex and MLF.
• In MS, MLF involvement is the most common cause of INO; combined lesions yield one-and-a-half syndrome.
• Always test both horizontal gaze and convergence separately to distinguish INO, gaze palsy, and convergence defects.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Failing to test abduction on the ipsilateral side, leading to misdiagnosis of INO rather than one-and-a-half syndrome.
2. Assuming convergence deficits in all MLF lesions; convergence is mediated by different pathways and is preserved in MLF syndromes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Thompson AJ et al., Revised 2017 McDonald Criteria (Lancet Neurol 2018): Recommend including brainstem manifestations (e.g., MLF lesions) for dissemination in space; use ≥3 T MRI with FLAIR and contrast enhancement.
2. National MS Society Consensus Guidelines (2018): IV methylprednisolone 500–1000 mg daily for 3–5 days for acute MS relapses (Level A evidence) to hasten recovery of focal neurological deficits.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The abducens nucleus (dorsal pons) contains motor neurons for lateral rectus and interneurons that travel via the MLF to the contralateral oculomotor nucleus. A lesion here abolishes both ipsilateral horizontal gaze and contralateral adduction, while sparing vertical movements and convergence.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Multiple sclerosis causes immune‐mediated demyelination and axonal injury. In the brainstem, this disrupts saltatory conduction in the MLF and abducens complexes, leading to internuclear ophthalmoplegia and gaze palsy when both structures are affected.

Neuroimaging Pearls

High‐resolution 3 T MRI T2/FLAIR images often show hyperintense plaques in the dorsal pons. Active lesions enhance with gadolinium; diffusion‐weighted imaging may show restricted diffusion if acute.

[Exam: Part I 2024] Miller Fisher syndrome (MFS) is an acute, immune‐mediated neuropathy and a variant of Guillain–Barré syndrome (GBS) defined by the triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and areflexia. Key principles:
• Gangliosides are glycolipids enriched in peripheral nerve membranes; specific anti‐ganglioside antibodies produce distinct clinical phenotypes.
• GQ1b ganglioside is abundant in oculomotor nerve roots and muscle spindle afferents, explaining ocular motor dysfunction and sensory ataxia.
• Absence of antecedent infection/vaccination does not exclude MFS; serology remains diagnostic. (110 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Anti‐GQ1b IgG is detected in >90% of MFS cases and has a specificity >99% (Chiba et al., Ann Neurol 1993). Binding of anti‐GQ1b to paranodal regions of cranial nerves III–VI and muscle spindle afferents triggers complement‐mediated conduction block, resulting in ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and areflexia. The 2021 EAN/PNS guideline recommends anti‐GQ1b testing to confirm MFS (Level B). Neither anti‐GM1 (linked to acute motor axonal neuropathy), anti‐AQP4 (central astrocytopathy in neuromyelitis optica), nor anti‐MAG (chronic demyelinating paraproteinemic neuropathy) produce this acute triad.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Anti‐GM1
• Linked to acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN) with pure motor weakness and preserved sensation.
• Misconception: all anti‐ganglioside antibodies cause ophthalmoplegia.
• GM1 is concentrated in motor axons, not ocular motor or proprioceptive fibers.

C. Anti‐AQP4
• Targets astrocytic water channels in CNS, causing optic neuritis and longitudinally extensive myelitis.
• Misconception: central demyelination underlies peripheral ophthalmoplegia.
• MRI shows spinal cord lesions versus normal peripheral nerve imaging in MFS.

D. Anti‐MAG
• Associated with chronic, distal demyelinating sensory neuropathy in IgM paraproteinemia.
• Misconception: any sensory ataxia stems from anti‐MAG.
• Slow progression over months/years, no acute ophthalmoplegia or areflexia pattern.

• Distinguish sensory ataxia (proprioceptive) from cerebellar ataxia by preserved head impulse and normal cerebellar imaging.
• Early IVIG or plasma exchange accelerates recovery even without prior infection.

1. Mistaking peripheral ocular motor neuropathy for a central lesion, leading to unnecessary brain imaging.
2. Assuming albuminocytologic dissociation is always present; CSF protein may be normal in early MFS.
3. Grouping all anti‐ganglioside antibodies under a single neuropathic phenotype rather than variant-specific patterns.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. European Academy of Neurology/Peripheral Nerve Society guideline (2021): recommends anti‐GQ1b IgG measurement in suspected MFS cases to confirm diagnosis (Level B evidence).
2. Mori M et al., Systematic Review and Meta‐analysis (J Neurol 2022): pooled data from 15 studies showing anti‐GQ1b IgG sensitivity 95% (90–98%) and specificity 99% (97–100%) in MFS (Level A evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

GQ1b gangliosides are localized in the paranodes of cranial nerves III, IV, and VI and in muscle spindle afferent terminals, accounting for ophthalmoplegia and sensory ataxia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Anti‐GQ1b IgG fixes complement at the nodes of Ranvier in peripheral nerves, causing reversible conduction block without significant axonal degeneration, leading to the acute triad of MFS.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Identify clinical triad: ophthalmoplegia + ataxia + areflexia.
2. Exclude central causes via MRI if “red flags” present.
3. Perform nerve conduction studies: look for sensory conduction block.
4. Confirm with anti‐GQ1b IgG serology; obtain CSF (albuminocytologic dissociation may appear later).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First‐line: IVIG 0.4 g/kg/day for 5 days or plasma exchange (4–6 sessions over 2 weeks) to hasten neurological recovery (AAN practice parameters).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2024] • Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an immune‐mediated demyelinating disorder of the central nervous system; relapsing–remitting MS (RRMS) features episodic inflammatory activity.
• Disease-modifying therapies (DMTs) are stratified by potency: fingolimod (S1P receptor modulator) is a moderate-to-high-efficacy oral agent that reduces lymphocyte egress from lymph nodes.
• Breakthrough disease—new MRI lesions or relapses on therapy—warrants escalation to a higher-efficacy DMT to prevent accrual of irreversible disability.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Natalizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against α4-integrin that prevents lymphocyte transmigration across the blood–brain barrier.
• AFFIRM trial (2006): natalizumab reduced annualized relapse rate by 68% vs placebo (p<0.001) and new MRI lesions by 83%.
• AAN 2018 guidelines (Level A evidence) recommend switching to a high-efficacy agent (e.g., natalizumab or anti-CD20) if there is breakthrough MRI activity on moderate-efficacy therapy.
• 2022 ECTRIMS/EAN guidelines: define treatment failure as new T1 gadolinium-enhancing or ≥3 new T2 lesions and endorse escalation to agents like natalizumab.
• Practical considerations: test JC virus antibody status and monitor for PML risk; if JCV index low (<0.9), natalizumab is preferred.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Glatiramer Acetate
• Incorrect: a low-potency immunomodulator; minimal impact on established breakthrough lesions.
• Misconception: assuming all DMTs are interchangeable in escalation.
• Differentiator: primarily shifts T-cell response to Th2 phenotype, less effective than natalizumab in active disease.

C. Interferon beta
• Incorrect: moderate efficacy, insufficient to control new gadolinium-enhancing lesions in an active RRMS patient.
• Misconception: continuing first-line therapy despite objective MRI evidence of failure.
• Differentiator: mechanism via cytokine modulation and MHC downregulation, but lower relapse reduction (~30%) vs natalizumab’s ~68%.

D. Dimethyl fumarate
• Incorrect: oral moderate-efficacy agent; not indicated for escalation after fingolimod failure.
• Misconception: stacking multiple oral DMTs yields better outcomes.
• Differentiator: activates Nrf2 antioxidant pathway; relapse reduction ~50%, less than natalizumab.

[Exam: Part I 2024] - Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a systemic autoimmune synovitis that frequently involves small joints and can extend to the cervical spine, especially the atlantoaxial joint.
• Pannus is hyperplastic, granulation tissue arising from inflamed synovium, which in the cervical spine can encroach on the cord, producing myelopathic signs (e.g., bilateral hand tingling).
• Differentiation between cord compression by pannus versus degenerative processes (disc herniation, osteophytes) requires MRI signal characteristics and clinical history of inflammatory arthritis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Rheumatoid pannus is the correct diagnosis. In RA, chronic synovitis leads to pannus formation that erodes bone and ligaments at C1–C2. MRI typically shows an isointense to hypointense mass on T1-weighted images and variable T2 signal with contrast enhancement posterior to the odontoid, compressing the spinal cord. The 2010 ACR/EULAR classification criteria for RA emphasize synovitis in small joints and systemic features; when patients with RA develop neck pain or neurological signs, cervical imaging is mandatory. A 2017 cohort study (Goepp et al.) found atlantoaxial subluxation and pannus in 18% of RA patients, with 60% demonstrating cord compression on MRI. Current EULAR 2019 recommendations advise that symptomatic RA patients undergo flexion-extension radiographs first, followed by MRI if neurological signs are present. High-resolution MRI is superior to CT for soft tissue evaluation and guides timing of cervical stabilization surgery to prevent irreversible myelopathy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Disc Compression
• Why incorrect: Disc herniation typically originates from nucleus pulposus extrusion at C5–C6 or C6–C7, not at C1–C2. Imaging would show focal disc bulge, not enhancing synovial mass.
• Misconception: Assuming any cord compression equals disc disease.
• Differentiator: Lack of systemic arthritis history and MRI appearance.

C. Spondylosis
• Why incorrect: Spondylotic changes are degenerative osteophytes and ligamentum flavum hypertrophy, seen in older adults without inflammatory joint swelling.
• Misconception: Equating age-related changes with inflammatory etiology.
• Differentiator: On MRI, osteophytes are hypointense on all sequences and non-enhancing.

D. Cervical Radiculopathy
• Why incorrect: Radiculopathy produces unilateral dermatomal pain/weakness, whereas this patient has bilateral hand tingling and neck pain with systemic RA.
• Misconception: Mistaking myelopathic paresthesias for radicular pain.
• Differentiator: Radiculopathy shows root compression; here, cord compression by pannus.

- Always screen RA patients with neck symptoms using flexion-extension cervical radiographs before MRI to detect atlantoaxial instability.
• Pannus formation can progress insidiously; early detection prevents irreversible cord damage.
• Contrast-enhanced MRI best delineates pannus from fibrous tissue or osteophytes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Interpreting bilateral hand tingling as bilateral radiculopathy rather than myelopathy.
• Attributing cervical symptoms in RA to “wear-and-tear” spondylosis without considering inflammatory pannus.

1. EULAR RA Management Recommendations 2019: Advise baseline cervical spine imaging in RA patients with neck pain or neurological signs (Level of Evidence: 2b).
2. ACR 2023 RA Treatment Guidelines: Emphasize early DMARD therapy to reduce pannus and joint destruction, potentially lowering cervical spine involvement (Level A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The pannus at C1–C2 compresses the upper cervical cord, affecting dorsal columns (vibration/position sense) and lateral corticospinal tracts (leading to hyperreflexia below the lesion).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic synovitis in RA drives pannus development: proliferating fibroblast-like synoviocytes, inflammatory infiltrates (T cells, macrophages), and neovascularization erode bone and ligaments.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: RA diagnosis, neck pain, hand paresthesias
2. Physical Exam: Myelopathic signs (hyperreflexia, Babinski)
3. Radiographs: Flexion-extension views for instability
4. MRI Cervical Spine: Evaluate soft tissue, pannus, cord compression

Neuroimaging Pearls

- T1-weighted MRI: Pannus appears isointense; contrast enhancement confirms active synovitis.
• T2-weighted MRI: Hyperintense signal in cord indicates myelomalacia.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Early initiation of methotrexate and biologic DMARDs (e.g., TNF inhibitors) reduces synovial proliferation and may slow pannus formation.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2024 exam. Cervical spine involvement in RA is a high-yield topic on neurology and rheumatology boards, often tested via imaging case vignettes highlighting pannus versus degenerative changes.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] - Autoimmune encephalitis: antibody-mediated disruption of synaptic receptors or intracellular neuronal proteins, leading to neuropsychiatric and seizure manifestations.
• NMDA receptors (GluN1/GluN2 subunits) are critical for excitatory neurotransmission, synaptic plasticity, and memory; autoantibodies cause receptor internalization and hypofunction.
• Typical anti-NMDAR encephalitis: adolescent females with subacute psychiatric symptoms, memory deficits, seizures, autonomic instability; MRI often normal, EEG may show non-specific slowing. (120 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis is the prototypical synaptic autoimmune encephalitis in young women. Dalmau et al. (Lancet Neurol 2011) first characterized IgG autoantibodies against the GluN1 subunit causing receptor cross-linking and internalization. Clinical criteria (Graus et al., Lancet Neurol 2016) emphasize: subacute onset (<3 months) of memory deficits, behavioral changes, seizures, CSF pleocytosis and exclusion of viral etiologies. MRI is normal in ~50%, EEG shows diffuse slowing or “extreme delta brush” in 30%. First-line immunotherapy (steroids + IVIG or plasmapheresis) and tumor removal (ovarian teratoma in ~50% of adult females) yield >70% good outcomes (Titulaer et al., NEJM 2013). Negative HSV/VZV PCR and lack of MRI/EEG focal lesions further point away from infectious encephalitis toward anti-NMDAR.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Hu antibody
• Targets intracellular neuronal antigens in paraneoplastic encephalomyelitis, typically small-cell lung cancer.
• Presents with sensory neuronopathy, cerebellar ataxia, limbic dysfunction in older smokers.
• Does not cause subacute psychosis or isolated seizures in adolescents.

C. Voltage gated potassium channel antibody
• Now attributed mostly to LGI1 and CASPR2 subtypes; LGI1 causes faciobrachial dystonic seizures and hyponatremia in middle-aged males.
• MRI often shows mesial temporal FLAIR hyperintensities; EEG reveals faciobrachial episodes.
• Age, seizure type, and MRI/EEG findings differ from anti-NMDAR.

D. GABA-B receptor antibody
• Associated with limbic encephalitis and small-cell lung carcinoma in older adults.
• Prominent refractory seizures and memory loss, with MRI temporal lobe changes.
• Rare in adolescents and less psychiatric prodrome than anti-NMDAR.

• Always screen young women with anti-NMDAR encephalitis for ovarian teratoma using pelvic MRI/ultrasound.
• Early immunotherapy (within 30 days of symptom onset) correlates with better neurological recovery (Titulaer et al., NEJM 2013).

1. Normal MRI/EEG excludes autoimmune encephalitis – imaging can be unremarkable in 40–50%.
2. Assuming negative viral PCR rules out all encephalitides – CSF antibody panels remain essential.

- Graus F et al., “A clinical approach to diagnosis of autoimmune encephalitis,” Lancet Neurol 2016: Consensus diagnostic criteria; Level C evidence.
• Armangue T et al., “Pediatric anti-NMDAR encephalitis: clinical analysis and outcome,” Neurology 2021: Recommends first-line steroids + IVIG/PLEX, early tumor resection; Level B evidence.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Anti-NMDAR antibodies target hippocampal and cortical NMDA receptors, disrupting glutamatergic synapses crucial for memory consolidation and behavior regulation.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

IgG autoantibodies bind the extracellular domain of the GluN1 subunit, causing receptor cross-linking, internalization, and synaptic hypofunction, which manifests as psychiatric and seizure activity.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect autoimmune encephalitis in subacute psychiatric/seizure syndrome.
2. Obtain CSF: cell count, protein, oligoclonal bands, autoimmune encephalitis panel.
3. MRI brain ± pelvic imaging for teratoma.
4. EEG for diffuse slowing or extreme delta brush.
5. Initiate empirical immunotherapy pending antibody results.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Brain MRI may be normal; if present, FLAIR hyperintensities localize to medial temporal lobes. Pelvic imaging is crucial for teratoma detection.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First-line: high-dose IV methylprednisolone (1 g/day ×5 days) + IVIG (2 g/kg over 2–5 days) or plasmapheresis. Second-line: rituximab (375 mg/m² weekly ×4) or cyclophosphamide (750 mg/m² monthly).

Board Examination Focus

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2024] Multiple sclerosis (MS) is defined by immune-mediated demyelination in the central nervous system, producing discrete clinical events called relapses. Clinically Isolated Syndrome (CIS) is the first episode of neurological dysfunction (e.g., optic neuritis) with MRI evidence of demyelination but insufficient criteria for MS. Diagnostic criteria require dissemination in space (DIS) – lesions in ≥2 of four regions (periventricular, juxtacortical, infratentorial, spinal cord) – and dissemination in time (DIT) – new lesions over time or CSF oligoclonal bands. A single periventricular lesion does not fulfill DIS, so the presentation remains CIS until further events or imaging findings confirm MS.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Clinically, a solitary episode of optic neuritis plus a single periventricular T2 lesion meets CIS but not MS by the 2017 McDonald criteria (Thompson et al., Lancet Neurol 2018). DIS requires ≥2 typical regions; here only the periventricular zone is involved. DIT is also absent: no new lesions on serial MRI and no reported CSF analysis. CIS converts to MS in ~60–80% of cases within 10 years if additional lesions appear, especially when ≥2 lesions are present at onset (Sormani et al., Ann Neurol 2011). Early identification guides monitoring and treatment initiation.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Relapsing-Remitting MS (RRMS)
• Incorrect because RRMS demands ≥2 clinical relapses separated by ≥30 days or MRI evidence of both DIS and DIT. A single event and one lesion lack DIT.
• Misconception: equating optic neuritis plus one lesion with RRMS.

C. Secondary Progressive MS
• Occurs only after an RRMS phase, with steady disability progression over ≥6 months. No prior relapses or progressive course here.
• Misconception: any progressive symptoms after CIS indicate SPMS.

D. Primary Progressive MS
• Characterized by gradual neurological worsening from onset, not discrete attacks. Requires one year of progression plus DIS on MRI or CSF OCB. Absent here.
• Misconception: attributing single-event progression to PPMS.

Clinical Pearls

1. Optic neuritis is the most common CIS manifestation; administer IV methylprednisolone (1 g/day for 3–5 days) to accelerate visual recovery.
2. CSF oligoclonal IgG bands can substitute for DIT but not for DIS per 2017 McDonald criteria.
3. Risk of conversion from CIS to MS is proportional to baseline lesion burden; ≥2 T2 lesions confer higher risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming a single MRI lesion equals DIS – students often overlook the requirement for ≥2 distinct CNS regions.
2. Believing CSF oligoclonal bands can replace DIS – they only substitute for DIT under McDonald 2017 guidelines.
3. Confusing Radiologically Isolated Syndrome (RIS) with CIS – RIS lacks clinical symptoms despite MRI findings.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• 2017 McDonald Criteria (Thompson AJ et al., Lancet Neurol 2018): Defines DIS as ≥2 of four typical CNS regions and allows CSF oligoclonal bands to meet DIT (Level A evidence).
• MAGNIMS Consensus Guidelines (Filippi et al., Lancet Neurol 2016): Recommend ≥3 periventricular lesions for high specificity in DIS and stress juxtacortical involvement.
• ECTRIMS/EAN 2018 Guidelines (Rae-Grant et al., Mult Scler 2018): Advocate early disease-modifying therapy after CIS if MRI lesion count is high (Level A).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2024] Multiple sclerosis is an immune‐mediated demyelinating disease of the central nervous system characterized by focal plaques of myelin loss. Key concepts:
• Perivenular inflammation: Lymphocytes and macrophages cross the blood–brain barrier at post‐capillary venules, initiating local demyelination.
• Histopathology: MS plaques show perivascular cuffing around small veins (venules) with oligodendrocyte injury and myelin debris.
• Neuroimaging correlate: The "central vein sign" on high‐resolution MRI and Dawson’s fingers oriented around medullary venules reflect this perivenular pattern.

Evidence-Based Analysis

MS lesions arise preferentially around post‐capillary venules due to selective upregulation of adhesion molecules (P‐selectin, ICAM‐1) on venular endothelium facilitating lymphocyte diapedesis. Histopathological studies (Adams et al., Ann Neurol 1987) consistently demonstrate perivenular cuffing as the earliest lesion feature. MRI studies have validated the "central vein sign" (Sati et al., Radiology 2016), showing that ≥40% of white matter lesions containing a visible central vein yields >85% specificity and 80% sensitivity for MS versus small‐vessel ischemic disease. The 2017 MAGNIMS consensus further supports using the central vein sign in research and diagnostic algorithms (Ciotti et al., Mult Scler J 2017).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Oligodendrocytes cell body
• Incorrect because lesions are defined by perivascular demyelination of myelin sheath, not destruction centered on oligodendrocyte somata.
• Misconception: Equating site of myelin production with lesion locus; in reality, oligodendrocyte injury is secondary to perivenular inflammation.

C. Arterioles
• Arterioles have thick muscular walls and do not express the adhesion molecules required for significant leukocyte extravasation seen in MS.
• Misconception: Assuming any small vessel can be entry point for immune cells; in fact, diapedesis occurs predominantly in post‐capillary venules.

D. Capillaries
• Capillaries lack the histological and molecular framework (pericytes, selectins) for focal immune cell trafficking seen in MS plaques.
• Misconception: Believing the smallest vessels are primary sites of inflammation; pathological studies refute capillary‐centered lesions.

Clinical Pearls

1. The central vein sign on 3T or 7T MRI (T2*/FLAIR sequences) is present in >80% of MS lesions and helps differentiate MS from mimics.
2. Dawson’s fingers—ovoid plaques radiating perpendicularly from the ventricles—reflect perivenular demyelination along medullary veins.
3. Small‐vessel ischemic changes typically spare the perivenular pattern and lack a central vein on susceptibility‐weighted imaging.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Confusing the locus of myelin production (oligodendrocytes) with the site of lesion formation.
• Overlooking that leukocyte extravasation in CNS inflammation occurs mainly in post‐capillary venules, not arterioles or capillaries.
• Misattributing periventricular hyperintensities without a central vein sign to MS, leading to overdiagnosis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• Sati P et al., "Consensus definition of the central vein sign in MS," Radiology 2016. Recommendation: ≥40% of white matter lesions with a central vein on T2*/FLAIR yields high diagnostic accuracy for MS. Level II evidence.
• MAGNIMS Consortium, "MRI in diagnosis and monitoring of MS," Mult Scler J 2017. Recommendation: Incorporate central vein sign as an adjunct in research and challenging diagnostic cases. Level II evidence.
• North American Imaging in MS Cooperative (NAIMS), "Central vein sign: Consensus recommendations," Neurology 2020. Recommendation: Use central vein sign in equivocal cases to improve specificity. Level III evidence.

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an immune-mediated demyelinating disease influenced by both genetic predisposition and environmental exposures. Key concepts:
• Odds ratio (OR): in case-control studies, OR = (odds of exposure in cases)/(odds of exposure in controls); OR >1 suggests increased risk.
• Smoking: a modifiable environmental risk factor shown to amplify central nervous system inflammation, increase blood–brain barrier permeability, and promote oxidative stress.
• Gene–environment interaction: particularly between tobacco exposure and HLA-DRB1*15:01, which further elevates MS susceptibility.

Evidence-Based Analysis

In question #187 of the Promotion 2018 exam, pooled data from multiple case-control and cohort studies establish an OR of approximately 1.6 for ever-smokers versus never-smokers. A 2017 meta-analysis (O’Gorman et al., JAMA Neurol 2017) incorporating 20 studies reported:
• OR 1.48 (95% CI 1.39–1.57) for ever-smokers
• OR 1.61 (95% CI 1.45–1.78) for current smokers
Hedström et al. (2014) in the Swedish EIMS cohort similarly found OR 1.6 (95% CI 1.4–1.8) for daily smokers. Thus, option B (1.6) aligns with robust epidemiological evidence. Higher values (2.0, 3.6) pertain to heavy smoking or gene–environment subgroups; lower values (1.3) underestimate the association.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. 1.3
• Underestimates the pooled OR; corresponds to the lower bound of some confidence intervals rather than the point estimate.
• Misconception: equating lowest CI limit with the mean effect size.

C. 2.0
• Reflects OR in select analyses of heavy smokers or subgroups but overestimates the average population risk.
• Misconception: assuming heavy-smoker subgroup data apply to all smokers.

D. 3.6
• Represents the OR for smokers who also carry HLA-DRB1*15:01 (gene–environment synergy), not the baseline risk for the general smoking population.
• Misconception: conflating interaction effects with main effects.

Clinical Pearls

- Smoking cessation reduces not only MS risk (~50–60% increase) but also delays conversion from clinically isolated syndrome to definite MS.
• The combination of smoking and HLA-DRB1*15:01 increases MS odds up to 2.5–3.6, underscoring gene–environment synergy.
• Advise all at-risk individuals (e.g., first-degree relatives) on tobacco avoidance to mitigate disease onset and progression.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing odds ratio with relative risk; although MS is rare, OR approximates RR only under low prevalence.
• Assuming only heavy smoking confers risk; even moderate smoking elevates MS odds.
• Overlooking genetic modifiers; the raw OR differs markedly when stratified by HLA allele status.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2021 Guidelines: Classify smoking as a modifiable MS risk factor; recommend incorporating smoking cessation counseling into preventive strategies (Level B evidence).
• ECTRIMS/EAN 2019 Focused Update: Advises “tobacco avoidance” for individuals with first-degree relatives with MS to reduce disease incidence (Class II evidence).

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can involve the nervous system in up to 40–90% of patients (neuropsychiatric SLE, NPSLE). Key relevant concepts:
• Autoimmune inflammation: Immune complex deposition and anti-neuronal antibodies (e.g., anti-ribosomal P, anti-NR2) cause diffuse CNS dysfunction.
• CSF findings: Lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and oligoclonal bands indicate intrathecal IgG synthesis, typical of inflammatory CNS processes.
• Differential diagnosis: Distinguish autoimmune cerebritis from infection (HSV encephalitis shows RBCs, PCR positivity) and from non‐inflammatory conditions (PRES, CVT).

Evidence-Based Analysis

SLE cerebritis (diffuse NPSLE) manifests with seizures and acute behavioral changes. CSF pleocytosis (usually <100 cells/mm³, predominantly lymphocytes) with positive oligoclonal bands reflects intrathecal autoantibody production (Bertsias et al., Ann Rheum Dis 2010). The 2019 EULAR/ACR classification criteria for SLE assign weighted points to neurologic features (seizures: 5 points), facilitating recognition of NPSLE (Aringer et al., Arthritis Rheumatol 2019). Imaging is often non‐specific or normal; definitive exclusion of infection by PCR and culture is mandatory. First-line therapy per 2019 EULAR recommendations: high-dose corticosteroids ± cyclophosphamide for severe diffuse NPSLE (Fanouriakis et al., Ann Rheum Dis 2020).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis
• Why incorrect: Typically shows red blood cell‐predominant CSF, extremely high protein, positive HSV PCR; MRI with temporal lobe hyperintensities.
• Misconception: Assuming any lymphocytic CSF in SLE is viral—distinction relies on PCR and RBC count.

C. Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES)
• Why incorrect: Presents with headache, vision changes, seizures, but CSF is usually normal; MRI shows bilateral parieto‐occipital vasogenic edema without OCB.
• Misconception: Attributing seizures in hypertensive SLE nephritis to PRES without CSF inflammatory markers.

D. Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT)
• Why incorrect: Presents with headache, focal deficits, seizures; CSF may show elevated opening pressure but not OCB; MR venography demonstrates venous occlusion.
• Misconception: Linking antiphospholipid antibodies in SLE directly to thrombosis without considering CSF profile.

Clinical Pearls

- Neuropsychiatric SLE can present with diffuse (seizures, psychosis) or focal (stroke, myelopathy) syndromes; CSF OCB and pleocytosis support an inflammatory etiology.
• Always exclude CNS infection (PCR for HSV, cultures) before immunosuppression in NPSLE.
• High‐dose IV methylprednisolone followed by cyclophosphamide is the cornerstone for severe diffuse NPSLE.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overlooking OCB in CSF and attributing seizures to PRES in hypertensive SLE patients.
2. Misinterpreting mild pleocytosis as viral when intrathecal autoantibody synthesis is the driver.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- EULAR Recommendations for the Management of Neuropsychiatric SLE (Fanouriakis et al., Ann Rheum Dis 2020):
• Recommendation: High-dose corticosteroids plus cyclophosphamide for severe diffuse NPSLE. Level of evidence: III.
• 2019 EULAR/ACR Classification Criteria for SLE (Aringer et al., Arthritis Rheumatol 2019):
• Seizures score 5 points; positive ANA required. Level of evidence: I.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Autoantibodies (anti-ribosomal P, anti-NR2 glutamate receptor) cross the blood–brain barrier in SLE, bind neuronal antigens, and activate complement, causing microglial activation, cytokine release, and neuronal dysfunction leading to seizures and behavioral changes.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: identify seizures, cognitive or psychiatric symptoms.
2. Exclude infection: CSF PCR (HSV, enterovirus), cultures.
3. CSF analysis: cell count, protein, OCB, IgG index.
4. Neuroimaging: MRI (rule out PRES, CVT, focal lesions).
5. Autoantibody profile: anti-dsDNA, antiphospholipid, anti-NR2.
6. Initiate immunosuppression once infection is excluded.

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI in SLE cerebritis may show non‐specific FLAIR hyperintensities in subcortical white matter without restricted diffusion or hemorrhage, differentiating from PRES and HSV encephalitis.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- First-line: IV methylprednisolone 1 g/day × 3–5 days, then oral prednisone tapered.
• Add cyclophosphamide (500–1000 mg/m² monthly) for severe or refractory cases; switch to azathioprine/mycophenolate for maintenance.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2024] Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system characterized by focal inflammatory lesions (“plaques”) in white matter. Key neuroanatomical sites include periventricular regions, optic nerves, brainstem and spinal cord. Demyelination causes conduction block, while incomplete remyelination and secondary axonal loss lead to residual deficits. Clinically, most patients present with a relapsing–remitting course: acute attacks followed by partial or complete remission. Over successive relapses, incomplete recovery accumulates, producing permanent neurological disability. Familiarity with demyelinating patterns, relapse recovery and lesion localization is essential for diagnosis and differentiation from mimics such as neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorders (NMOSD). (Words: 117)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option B is correct because relapsing–remitting MS (RRMS) typically yields only partial remission of attacks, with residual deficits accumulating over time. The 2017 McDonald Criteria (Thompson et al., Lancet Neurol 2018) consider incomplete recovery a supportive feature of dissemination in time. A longitudinal cohort by Confavreux et al. (Brain 2000) demonstrated that by year 5, 80% of RRMS patients retained new disability from relapses. The 2021 American Academy of Neurology guidelines on disease-modifying therapies (Level A evidence) underscore that early initiation of high-efficacy treatments reduces relapse frequency and mitigates incomplete remission, thereby delaying secondary progression. Pathophysiologically, inflammatory demyelination injures oligodendrocytes and axons; remyelination is often insufficient, so conduction deficits persist.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Simultaneous bilateral optic neuritis would suggest looking for other diagnoses.
• Although bilateral optic neuritis is more common in NMOSD/MOGAD, it can occur (≈5%) in MS. It is not an absolute exclusion of MS.
• Misconception: bilateral involvement never occurs in MS.
• Unlike unilateral, painful, subacute optic neuritis in MS, bilateral simultaneous ON raises—but does not guarantee—alternative etiologies.

C. MS lesions are typically found only in the spinal cord.
• MS characteristically involves brain white matter (periventricular “Dawson’s fingers,” juxtacortical, infratentorial) and optic nerves as well as spinal cord.
• Misconception: thinking MS is a purely myelopathic disorder.
• True spinal cord-only demyelination without brain lesions suggests alternative diagnoses (e.g., transverse myelitis, NMOSD).

D. MS always presents with a progressive course from onset.
• Only 10–15% of patients have primary progressive MS; ~85% begin with relapsing–remitting MS.
• Misconception: equating MS with chronic progressive degeneration from the start.
• Relapsing–remitting onset with distinct attacks is the hallmark of most new MS cases.

Clinical Pearls

- Partial recovery with residual deficits is characteristic of RRMS and predicts faster accumulation of disability.
• Unilateral, painful, subacute optic neuritis is classic for MS; bilateral simultaneous cases warrant evaluation for NMOSD/MOGAD (AQP4/MOG antibodies).
• MRI “Dawson’s fingers” and CSF oligoclonal bands reinforce MS diagnosis; absence of brain lesions or simultaneous bilateral ON should prompt alternate workup.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Believing every MS relapse fully remits—early attacks may fully recover, but most leave some deficit.
2. Assuming bilateral optic neuritis excludes MS—rarely, MS can cause bilateral ON.
3. Thinking MS lesions are confined to the spinal cord—brain involvement is more prominent.
4. Equating MS with primary progressive course—relapsing–remitting onset predominates.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- 2017 McDonald Criteria (International Panel, 2018): Emphasize MRI dissemination in time/space and recognize incomplete remission as supportive for diagnosis (Level II).
• 2021 AAN Guideline on DMTs in MS: Recommends early high-efficacy therapy to reduce relapse burden and incomplete recovery (Level A).
• 2015 International Panel for NMO Diagnosis (IPND): Defines bilateral ON as a core feature of NMOSD, aiding differentiation from MS (expert consensus).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

MS plaques form in perivenular white matter tracts: periventricular radiations, corpus callosum, optic nerves, brainstem, cerebellar peduncles and spinal cord dorsal columns. Optic nerve demyelination disrupts visual signal conduction; periventricular lesions compromise motor and sensory pathways.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Autoreactive CD4+ Th1/Th17 cells and B cells cross the blood–brain barrier, activate microglia and macrophages, release cytokines and complement—leading to focal demyelination, oligodendrocyte apoptosis and secondary axonal transection. Remyelination is often incomplete, resulting in gliotic scars and persistent conduction deficits.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: neurologic deficits separated in time and space.
2. MRI brain/spine: periventricular, juxtacortical, infratentorial, spinal lesions; gadolinium enhancement for active plaques.
3. CSF analysis: oligoclonal IgG bands, elevated IgG index.
4. Exclude mimics: AQP4/MOG antibodies, infectious, vasculitic, metabolic.
5. Apply 2017 McDonald Criteria for definitive diagnosis.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- “Dawson’s fingers”: ovoid lesions perpendicular to lateral ventricles.
• T1 “black holes” indicate axonal loss.
• Spinal lesions are typically short (<2 vertebral segments) and peripheral.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Acute relapse: IV methylprednisolone 1 g daily for 3–5 days; consider plasma exchange if steroid-refractory.
• Disease-modifying therapies: interferon-β, glatiramer acetate, fingolimod, dimethyl fumarate, ocrelizumab; mechanisms include immunomodulation and B-cell depletion. Early initiation reduces incomplete remission and long-term disability.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2019] • Optic neuritis is an acute demyelinating inflammation of the optic nerve, often the first manifestation of MS.
• The inflamed optic nerve sheath stretches during extraocular movements, causing characteristic periocular pain.
• Visual loss is typically unilateral, subacute (over days), and associated with a relative afferent pupillary defect.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Pain on eye movement is seen in over 90% of MS‐related optic neuritis cases (Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial, ONTT, 1992). Inflammatory demyelination within the optic nerve and its sheath irritates pain fibers of the trigeminal nerve, leading to discomfort with extraocular muscle contraction. AAN Practice Parameter (2008, reaffirmed 2016) recommends high‐dose IV methylprednisolone to hasten visual recovery but does not alter long‐term outcome. MRI demonstrating periventricular white matter lesions increases the risk of conversion to clinically definite MS (up to 72% at 15 years if ≥1 lesion present).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Papillitis with papilledema
– Only ~35% of optic neuritis cases show optic disc edema (“papillitis”); most are retrobulbar with a normal disc. Conflates optic neuritis with increased intracranial pressure.
B. Bilateral optic neuritis
– MS typically causes unilateral involvement; bilateral acute optic neuritis suggests neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD) or infectious etiologies.
D. Sudden painless vision loss
– Painless presentations are more typical of vascular (e.g., anterior ischemic optic neuropathy) or compressive lesions; MS‐associated optic neuritis is painful.

• A relative afferent pupillary defect (Marcus Gunn pupil) is a sensitive sign even when the disc appears normal.
• High‐dose IV steroids speed recovery but do not impact long‐term visual acuity or MS conversion risk.
• Bilateral or recurrent optic neuritis warrants AQP4‐IgG testing to exclude NMOSD.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating any optic disc edema with MS‐optic neuritis rather than recognizing the typical “normal‐appearing” disc.
2. Assuming painless vision loss is optic neuritis, when it more commonly indicates ischemic or toxic etiologies.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial (ONTT), 1992: demonstrated benefit of IV steroids on recovery speed (Level I evidence).
• AAN Practice Parameter on Optic Neuritis (2008; reaffirmed 2016): recommends MRI within 2 weeks and high‐dose IV methylprednisolone for acute attacks (Level A).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an immune‐mediated demyelinating disorder in which B cells contribute via antigen presentation, pro‐inflammatory cytokine secretion, and formation of meningeal follicles. CD20 is a pan‐B‐cell surface marker (absent on stem cells and plasma cells) that allows targeted depletion of circulating B cells with minimal impact on existing antibody levels. Key terminology: antibody‐dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC), complement‐dependent cytotoxicity (CDC), and humanized versus chimeric monoclonal antibodies. Understanding the distinct targets of MS therapies (e.g., S1P receptors vs. CD20 vs. CD52 vs. IL-2R) is essential for matching mechanism to drug.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Ocrelizumab is a humanized IgG1 monoclonal antibody that binds CD20 on pre‐B and mature B lymphocytes, inducing depletion via ADCC, CDC, and apoptosis. In the OPERA I/II Phase III trials (Hauser et al., NEJM 2017), ocrelizumab reduced annualized relapse rate by ~46% compared to interferon β-1a and significantly suppressed MRI lesion activity. In the ORATORIO trial (Montalban et al., NEJM 2017), it showed a 24% risk reduction in 12-week confirmed disability progression in primary progressive MS (PPMS)—the first therapy to demonstrate efficacy in PPMS. The 2018 ECTRIMS/EAN guidelines give ocrelizumab a Level A recommendation for relapsing MS with high disease activity; the 2017 AAN guidelines similarly endorse its use (Level A). Ocrelizumab’s humanized structure reduces anti‐drug antibody formation compared to chimeric rituximab, improving tolerability. Current practice includes pre‐infusion steroids and antihistamines, hepatitis B screening, and periodic serum IgG monitoring to mitigate infection risk.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Sphingosine-1-phosphate receptor modulator
• Incorrect because these small molecules (e.g., fingolimod) bind S1P₁ on lymphocytes, sequestering them in lymph nodes rather than depleting B cells.
• Misconception: equating oral immunomodulators with monoclonal antibodies.
• Differentiator: mechanism is receptor modulation and lymphocyte trafficking, not cell lysis.

C. CD52
• Targets the CD52 antigen on all lymphocytes and monocytes (alemtuzumab), causing broad lymphocyte depletion and risk of secondary autoimmunity.
• Misconception: all depleting antibodies in MS hit the same B‐cell marker.
• Differentiator: CD52 is pan‐lymphocyte, CD20 is B‐cell specific.

D. Interleukin-2 receptor antagonist
• Daclizumab (withdrawn) bound CD25 (IL-2R α) on activated T cells, inhibiting T-cell proliferation.
• Misconception: associating T‐cell targeted therapies with B‐cell markers.
• Differentiator: IL-2R blockade modulates T cells, not B‐cell depletion.

1. Ocrelizumab is the first DMT approved for both relapsing MS and PPMS.
2. Always screen for hepatitis B (HBsAg, anti-HBc) before initiation due to reactivation risk.
3. Premedicate with methylprednisolone and antihistamine to reduce infusion reactions; monitor serum IgG annually.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing CD20 with CD52 leading to incorrect attribution of broad lymphocyte depletion effects to ocrelizumab.
2. Believing all monoclonal antibodies in MS share the same administration route and safety profile.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. 2018 ECTRIMS/EAN MS guidelines: Strong (Level A) recommendation for ocrelizumab in active relapsing MS (Montalban X et al., 2018).
2. 2017 American Academy of Neurology: Ocrelizumab receives Level A evidence for reducing relapse rate and MRI activity in relapsing MS (Hauser SL et al., 2017).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Dosing: Initial two 300 mg infusions two weeks apart, then 600 mg IV every six months.
• Monitoring: Baseline CBC, LFTs, hepatitis panel, immunoglobulins; annual IgG levels.
• Contraindications: Active infection; live vaccines within six weeks of infusion.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Acute seizures and confusion in an SLE patient require distinguishing primary neuropsychiatric SLE from secondary causes. Key concepts:
• Cerebral autoregulation: Maintains stable blood flow across mean arterial pressures (MAP) of 60–150 mmHg; failure leads to hyperperfusion and blood–brain barrier (BBB) disruption.
• Vasogenic vs. cytotoxic edema: Vasogenic edema (extracellular fluid) on MRI FLAIR appears as subcortical hyperintensities with increased apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC); cytotoxic edema (intracellular swelling) restricts diffusion.
• Risk factors in SLE: Hypertension, renal failure, dialysis-related fluid shifts, and immunosuppressants (e.g., calcineurin inhibitors) predispose to PRES rather than inflammatory cerebritis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Posterior Reversible Encephalopathy Syndrome (PRES) manifests with seizures, altered mental status, headache, and visual disturbances. Hinchey et al. (1996) first described PRES in hypertensive crises; subsequent studies (Feske et al., 2013) identified renal failure and immunosuppression as major contributors. In lupus cohorts, PRES incidence reaches up to 8% (Lee et al., 2019). MRI hallmark: bilateral parieto-occipital FLAIR hyperintensities without diffusion restriction, indicating vasogenic edema. CSF is typically unremarkable. Management per KDIGO (2021) focuses on gradual blood pressure reduction (target MAP <95 mmHg), removal or dose adjustment of offending agents, and seizure control with levetiracetam as first-line. Dialysis settings should be adjusted to minimize rapid osmotic shifts.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Lupus cerebritis
• Reason incorrect: NPSLE inflammatory cerebritis shows CSF pleocytosis, elevated IgG index, complement consumption, and multifocal or diffuse MRI lesions, not isolated posterior edema.
• Misconception: Labeling any SLE-related CNS event as “lupus cerebritis” without imaging/CSF corroboration.

C. Cerebral Venous Thrombosis (CVT)
• Reason incorrect: CVT presents with headache, focal deficits, papilledema; MRV demonstrates venous sinus occlusion and sometimes hemorrhagic infarction.
• Misconception: Assuming hypercoagulable SLE always leads to venous thrombosis when seizures occur.

D. Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) encephalitis
• Reason incorrect: HSV encephalitis produces fever, behavioral changes, focal temporal lobe hemorrhagic lesions on MRI, CSF with RBCs and positive HSV PCR.
• Misconception: Equating acute seizures and confusion in any immunosuppressed patient with viral encephalitis.

- The posterior circulation is more vulnerable in PRES due to sparse sympathetic innervation, explaining the parieto-occipital predilection.
• In SLE patients on dialysis, rapid ultrafiltration and uncontrolled hypertension are common PRES precipitants; always review recent dialysis records.
• First-line seizure prophylaxis in PRES is levetiracetam owing to minimal cytochrome P450 interactions with immunosuppressants.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Diagnosing “lupus cerebritis” without CSF analysis and characteristic MRI—leading to inappropriate immunosuppression intensification.
• Overlooking dialysis-induced osmotic shifts as PRES triggers, misattributing confusion to uremic encephalopathy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- KDIGO 2021 Clinical Practice Guideline for the Management of Blood Pressure in CKD
• Recommendation: Maintain BP <130/80 mmHg and MAP <95 mmHg to prevent neurologic complications, including PRES (LoE 1B).
• 2019 EULAR Recommendations for Management of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
• Recommendation: Employ MRI (FLAIR/DWI) and CSF studies to differentiate NPSLE from secondary causes like PRES; tailor immunosuppression accordingly (LoE 1C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Parieto-occipital regions have lower density of sympathetic vasoconstrictor fibers; when MAP exceeds autoregulatory capacity, these areas develop capillary leakage and vasogenic edema characteristic of PRES.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

1. Sudden or severe hypertension overwhelms cerebral autoregulation.
2. Endothelial dysfunction (exacerbated by uremia and calcineurin inhibitors) disrupts the BBB.
3. Plasma filtrates into interstitium → extracellular fluid accumulation (vasogenic edema).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Assess vitals and ensure airway/breathing.
2. Obtain emergent MRI with FLAIR, DWI/ADC, and MRV if indicated.
3. Perform CSF analysis to exclude infection/inflammation.
4. Review dialysis parameters and immunosuppressant levels.
5. Initiate BP control, adjust dialysis, and start seizure prophylaxis.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- FLAIR: symmetric, confluent subcortical white matter hyperintensities.
• ADC: elevated values distinguishing vasogenic from cytotoxic edema.
• DWI: lack of diffusion restriction confirms reversible edema.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- IV Nicardipine infusion titrated to reduce MAP by ≤25% in first hour.
• Levetiracetam 500–1000 mg IV BID for seizure control.
• Adjust or hold calcineurin inhibitors; optimize dialysis ultrafiltration rates.

[Exam: Part II 2022] Small-vessel vasculitis of the CNS, often termed primary angiitis of the CNS (PACNS), is an idiopathic inflammatory disorder targeting arterioles, capillaries and venules. Pathologically it causes segmental transmural inflammation, granuloma formation and fibrinoid necrosis. Clinically, patients present subacutely with headaches, cognitive decline, focal deficits or seizures. Neuroimaging (MRI) demonstrates multifocal T2/FLAIR white-matter lesions and leptomeningeal enhancement, while angiography only detects medium/large-vessel changes. Definitive diagnosis relies on histopathological confirmation via brain biopsy, showing perivascular lymphocytic or granulomatous infiltrates. Early immunosuppression (high-dose steroids ± cyclophosphamide) improves outcomes but may obscure biopsy findings if given prior to tissue sampling.
(Word count: 122)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Brain biopsy remains the diagnostic gold standard for CNS small-vessel vasculitis. According to Calabrese and Mallek’s seminal criteria (Neurology 1988;38:231–237), histological demonstration of transmural inflammation and granulomas in small parenchymal vessels definitively establishes the diagnosis. UpToDate (2024) reinforces that non-invasive tests—MRI, angiography, CSF analysis—lack specificity for small-vessel involvement. In a series of 90 PACNS patients (Obeidat et al., J Neurol Sci. 2018;387:86–93), biopsy yielded diagnostic tissue in 75% of cases, guiding targeted immunotherapy. Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) misses lesions below its 500-µm resolution threshold (Salvarani et al., Arthritis Rheum. 2007;56:111–119), and MRI patterns overlap with demyelination, infection or malignancy. Empirical corticosteroid response is neither sensitive nor specific—multiple mimics (e.g., reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome) also improve transiently with steroids.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Respond to corticosteroids
• Why incorrect: Steroid responsiveness is non-specific; CNS infections, neoplastic processes and RCVS can transiently improve.
• Misconception: Equating clinical improvement with underlying vasculitis.
• Key differentiator: Only histology confirms transmural vascular inflammation.

C. Digital subtraction angiography (DSA)
• Why incorrect: Detects medium/large artery “beading” but fails to visualize arterioles/capillaries (<500 µm).
• Misconception: Angiographic patterns suffice for all vasculitides.
• Key differentiator: Small-vessel changes are below angiographic resolution; false negatives common.

D. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
• Why incorrect: MRI findings (white-matter hyperintensities, leptomeningeal enhancement) are sensitive but not pathognomonic.
• Misconception: MRI lesions confirm vasculitis.
• Key differentiator: Biopsy provides cellular detail; MRI only suggests inflammatory patterns.

• Obtain brain biopsy prior to or within 48 hours of starting high-dose steroids to preserve histological integrity.
• Target biopsy to areas of radiographic abnormality—leptomeningeal enhancement on MRI improves yield.
• Consider leptomeningeal and cortical sampling in suspected PACNS; purely white-matter biopsies carry higher false-negative rates.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Delaying biopsy while pursuing extended non-invasive workup—may lead to irreversible neurologic deficits and reduced tissue yield.
2. Mistaking RCVS (reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome) for PACNS—RCVS shows reversible vessel narrowing on serial angiography and lacks vessel wall inflammation on biopsy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International Chapel Hill Consensus Conference (CHCC) 2012
– Classification defines PACNS as small-vessel‐predominant CNS vasculitis without systemic involvement (Level of Evidence: Consensus).
2. American College of Radiology (ACR) Appropriateness Criteria 2019: CNS Inflammatory Diseases
– Recommends brain biopsy for suspected small-vessel vasculitis when MRI/angiography are nondiagnostic (Rating: 8/9, Moderate evidence).
3. UpToDate (2024) “Primary angiitis of the CNS: Diagnostic evaluation”
– Advises prompt biopsy in steroid-naïve patients with high clinical suspicion (Expert opinion).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: subacute headache, cognitive change, focal deficits.
2. MRI brain with contrast + CSF analysis to exclude infection/malignancy.
3. DSA if medium/large-vessel vasculitis suspected.
4. If noninvasive tests inconclusive and high suspicion remains → stereotactic brain biopsy of enhancing region.
5. Histopathological confirmation → initiate targeted immunosuppression.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• High-resolution vessel-wall MRI can detect concentric wall thickening/enhancement in medium vessels but lacks resolution for arterioles.
• Multifocal T2/FLAIR hyperintensities with leptomeningeal enhancement suggest inflammatory vasculitis rather than ischemia alone.

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic immune-mediated demyelinating disease of the central nervous system. Epidemiological studies quantify associations between exposures and disease using odds ratios (OR). An OR >1 indicates increased risk. Key modifiable/exogenous risk factors for MS include Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection manifesting as infectious mononucleosis, low ultraviolet light exposure (affecting vitamin D synthesis), and true vitamin D deficiency. Understanding both the strength of these associations (OR values) and underlying immunopathology is crucial for interpreting exam questions on MS epidemiology.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Infectious mononucleosis represents symptomatic primary EBV infection and is the most consistently replicated environmental risk factor for MS. A meta-analysis of 17 case-control studies (Smolders et al., 2019) reported a pooled OR of 2.17 (95% CI 1.92–2.46), while some population-based cohorts yield an OR of ~1.4 when adjusting for confounders (Ascherio et al., 2010). Virtually 100% of MS patients are EBV-seropositive (Bjornevik et al., 2022; Nature), and longitudinal data show EBV seroconversion precedes MS onset by years (hazard ratio >30). Mechanistically, EBV-infected memory B cells infiltrate the CNS, promoting molecular mimicry and chronic inflammation. Current ECTRIMS/EAN guidelines (2018) recognize EBV as a probable causal factor (Level C evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Low sunlight exposure
– Although low UVB exposure increases MS risk (OR ~1.8–2.5), the OR does not match 1.4. It is a proxy for vitamin D status rather than a direct measurement.
– Misconception: equating any low-UV environment with an OR of 1.4.
– Differentiator: studies report stronger associations (OR >1.8).

B. Shift work
– Night-shift work has been hypothesized to affect circadian regulation of immunity, but large studies have not confirmed a consistent MS risk (OR not significantly >1).
– Misconception: all circadian disruptions translate to autoimmunity.
– Differentiator: lack of robust, replicated epidemiological data.

C. Vitamin D deficiency
– Low 25-OH vitamin D levels are linked to higher MS risk; nested case-control data show OR ~1.2–1.6 per 25 nmol/L decrement, not a single OR of 1.4 for deficiency per se.
– Misconception: equating any threshold of “deficiency” with a uniform OR.
– Differentiator: dose-response relationship rather than a binary OR.

Clinical Pearls

- Symptomatic EBV infection (infectious mononucleosis) confers a markedly higher MS risk than asymptomatic seroconversion.
• Maintain serum 25-OH vitamin D >40 ng/mL in individuals with clinically isolated syndrome to potentially delay MS onset.
• Gene–environment interactions (e.g., HLA-DRB1*15:01 with smoking or EBV) amplify MS susceptibility.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming any EBV seropositivity (vs. mononucleosis) carries the same OR for MS.
2. Misreading OR as a direct measure of absolute risk rather than relative association.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. ECTRIMS/EAN Consensus Guideline on MS Management (2018)
– Recommendation: Acknowledge EBV infection as a probable causal factor (Level C). Screen and supplement vitamin D in at-risk individuals (Grade 2).
2. Bjornevik L, Cortese M, Healy BC et al. “Longitudinal analysis reveals high risk of MS following EBV seroconversion.” Nature 603:321–327 (2022)
– Finding: EBV seroconversion precedes MS onset in >97% of cases; hazard ratio >30, providing Level I evidence for causality.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

EBV persists in latently infected memory B cells. Upon CNS entry, these cells present viral and cross-reactive myelin antigens, activating autoreactive T cells. The ensuing inflammatory cascade disrupts the blood-brain barrier, leading to focal demyelination and neurodegeneration characteristic of MS.

[Exam: Part II 2022] Giant cell arteritis (GCA) is a granulomatous vasculitis affecting medium- and large-sized arteries in patients over age 50, presenting with new temporal headache, jaw claudication, and elevated inflammatory markers. The anterior optic nerve head relies on short posterior ciliary arteries (branches of the ophthalmic artery). Inflammation of these vessels causes anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION), characterized by sudden, painless vision loss, a pale swollen optic disc, and altitudinal field defect. Jaw claudication reflects external carotid branch involvement and correlates strongly with the risk of vision loss. Differentiation from retinal vascular occlusions hinges on funduscopic findings: optic disc edema versus retinal whitening with a cherry-red spot.

Evidence-Based Analysis

In GCA, granulomatous infiltration of the short posterior ciliary arteries leads to luminal narrowing and infarction of the optic nerve head—AION. Hayreh et al. (2009) found AION to be the most frequent visual complication in untreated GCA (≈20%). The 2016 American College of Rheumatology guidelines recommend immediate high-dose corticosteroids upon clinical suspicion to prevent irreversible bilateral visual loss; confirmatory temporal artery biopsy or ultrasound can follow. The hallmark funduscopic finding is a pale, swollen optic disc without the cherry-red spot seen in retinal artery occlusions, confirming short ciliary artery involvement as the mechanism.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Retinal artery occlusion
• Incorrect: General term that includes branch occlusions with segmental retinal whitening; does not produce optic disc edema.
• Misconception: Assuming any vision loss with GCA is due to retinal vessels.
• Differentiator: Branch retinal artery occlusion shows localized whitening, not diffuse disc swelling.

C. Central retinal artery occlusion
• Incorrect: CRAO causes diffuse retinal pallor with a cherry-red spot at the fovea and sudden, severe visual loss.
• Misconception: Failing to distinguish retinal from optic nerve head ischemia.
• Differentiator: Cherry-red spot is absent in AION.

D. Giant cell arteritis (GCA)
• Incorrect: GCA is the systemic disease, not the direct vascular lesion causing vision loss.
• Misconception: Equating underlying condition with the specific anatomic cause.
• Differentiator: The question asks for the anatomic vascular event (short ciliary artery involvement).

Clinical Pearls

- Jaw claudication has ~90% specificity for GCA and predicts risk of vision loss.
• Initiate high-dose IV methylprednisolone before biopsy to protect the contralateral eye.
• A swollen, pale optic disc in an elderly patient with headache mandates evaluation for GCA.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing AION with CRAO by expecting a cherry-red spot rather than disc edema.
2. Selecting GCA (the underlying disease) instead of the specific vascular lesion causing vision loss.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American College of Rheumatology/Vasculitis Foundation (2021): Recommends prednisone 40–60 mg/day with rapid initiation; tocilizumab adjunct for refractory cases (Level A).
• EULAR (2018) update: Temporal artery ultrasound as first-line imaging—“halo sign” sensitivity ~75%, specificity ~90%.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Short posterior ciliary arteries form an anastomotic circle (circle of Zinn–Haller) supplying the anterior optic nerve head. In GCA, these vessels develop granulomatous inflammation leading to segmental infarction.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

T-cell–mediated granulomatous inflammation targets the internal elastic lamina, causing intimal hyperplasia and luminal occlusion. When short ciliary arteries are involved, this yields infarction of the optic nerve head (AION).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect GCA in patients >50 with new headache and jaw claudication
2. Check ESR, CRP (usually elevated)
3. Start high-dose steroids immediately
4. Perform temporal artery ultrasound (halo sign)
5. Confirm with temporal artery biopsy within 2 weeks

Neuroimaging Pearls

Temporal artery ultrasound shows a hypoechoic “halo” around the vessel wall indicating edema. High-resolution MRI can demonstrate vessel wall enhancement but is secondary to ultrasound.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First-line: IV methylprednisolone 500 mg–1 g daily for 3 days, then oral prednisone 1 mg/kg/day with taper over 1–2 years. Low-dose aspirin reduces ischemic complications (Level B evidence).

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Giant cell (temporal) arteritis (GCA) is a large‐vessel vasculitis seen in patients >50 years, characterized by granulomatous inflammation of branches of the external carotid artery. Key features include new-onset headache, visual disturbances (due to ophthalmic artery involvement), jaw claudication, and elevated acute‐phase reactants. Prompt recognition is critical to prevent irreversible vision loss from ischemic optic neuropathy. Measurement of ESR (and CRP) is the rapid initial test that supports the clinical suspicion and guides urgent management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

ESR is elevated in >90% of GCA cases; CRP adds sensitivity. According to the 2018 EULAR recommendations for large vessel vasculitis (class 1B), when GCA is suspected, obtain ESR/CRP immediately and initiate high‐dose glucocorticoids without waiting for biopsy results. Delaying therapy increases the risk of bilateral vision loss (Davies et al., 2016). Temporal artery biopsy remains the diagnostic gold standard but must follow prompt lab evaluation and steroid initiation. No other diagnostic modality (MRI, LP) provides as rapid or as specific data in suspected GCA.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Brain MRI
• Incorrect: MRI is neither sensitive nor specific for GCA; normal intracranial vessels may be seen despite active disease.
• Misconception: Attributing all new headaches in older patients to structural brain lesions.
• Differentiator: GCA is a systemic arteritis of extracranial branches; MRI of the brain adds delay without confirming vasculitis.

C. Lumbar Puncture
• Incorrect: LP evaluates CNS infections or subarachnoid hemorrhage, not large‐vessel arteritis.
• Misconception: Assuming headache plus visual symptoms mandates CSF analysis.
• Differentiator: GCA presents with systemic inflammatory markers, not CSF pleocytosis.

D. Ophthalmology Referral
• Incorrect: While urgent, referral should not precede laboratory confirmation and immediate steroid therapy.
• Misconception: Thinking specialist consultation alone addresses acute ischemic risk.
• Differentiator: Initial labs and steroids are critical to halt vascular inflammation before ophthalmologic evaluation.

- Always obtain ESR ± CRP immediately when GCA is suspected; do not delay steroids.
• Jaw claudication and scalp tenderness are highly specific for GCA.
• Temporal artery biopsy should be performed within 2 weeks of steroid initiation to maximize yield.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Waiting for biopsy before starting steroids, risking permanent vision loss.
2. Ordering brain imaging first due to “headache,” thereby delaying treatment.
3. Relying solely on temporal artery ultrasound; a negative scan does not exclude GCA.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- EULAR (2018): Recommend immediate ESR/CRP measurement and high‐dose glucocorticoids (1B).
• ACR/Vasculitis Foundation (2022): Endorse tocilizumab for steroid-refractory or relapsing GCA in combination with a prednisone taper (Level A evidence from the GiACTA trial).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

GCA affects branches of the external carotid artery, especially the superficial temporal artery and the ophthalmic artery (branch of the internal carotid), leading to ischemia of the optic nerve and retina.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Granulomatous inflammation of the arterial media and adventitial vasa vasorum causes intimal hyperplasia, luminal narrowing, and downstream ischemia—manifesting as headache, jaw claudication, and vision changes.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in patients >50 years with headache + visual symptoms
2. Immediately obtain ESR, CRP, platelet count
3. Start high‐dose glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone 40–60 mg daily)
4. Arrange temporal artery biopsy within 2 weeks
5. Consider adjunctive tocilizumab in relapsing cases

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Uncomplicated GCA: Prednisone 40–60 mg daily, taper over 12–18 months.
• Visual symptoms: Methylprednisolone 500–1000 mg IV daily ×3 days, then high‐dose oral taper.
• Tocilizumab: 162 mg SC weekly, for relapsing or steroid-sparing therapy.
